After Saladin’s death, the realm fragmented among relatives ruling in Cairo, Damascus, and Aleppo. Egyptian rulers remained pivotal due to grain revenues and fleet resources. In 1250, palace and field regiments deposed the last Ayyubid sultan in Egypt, establishing Mamluk rule. Ayyubid branches survived in Syria for a decade, but Mongol pressure and Egyptian dominance shifted leadership of the eastern Mediterranean to Cairo.

types.name: Aztec
types.description:
The Mexica (Aztec) established Tenochtitlan on Lake Texcoco c. 1325. After victory over Azcapotzalco in 1428 they formed the Triple Alliance with Texcoco and Tlacopan. Expansion under Itzcoatl, Moctezuma I, and Ahuitzotl created a large tributary empire. Chinampa agriculture, aqueducts, and dikes sustained dense urban life. Tlatelolco’s market linked regional trade. Education in calmecac and telpochcalli trained elites and commoners. Priests maintained complex ritual calendars and state cults centered on Huitzilopochtli and Tlaloc.
The capital’s Templo Mayor saw repeated expansions and major ceremonies. Poetry, codices, and fine featherwork flourished. Alliance warfare, strategic marriages, and vassal governors maintained control. In 1519–1521 Spanish-led forces, allied with Tlaxcala and other enemies of the empire, besieged and captured Tenochtitlan amid devastating epidemics. The city became the seat of the Viceroyalty of New Spain. Imperial institutions and labor systems were reshaped under colonial rule while Nahua communities adapted and persisted.

types.name: Babylon
types.description: Babylonian civilization consolidated in central-southern Mesopotamia during the Old Babylonian period (c. 2000–1595 BCE), reaching a peak under Hammurabi. His legal stele codified royal jurisprudence, property rules, and penalties, while canals and fortifications anchored the capital’s authority. Kassite kings then stabilized Babylonia for four centuries, integrating provincial cults and land grants. The Neo-Babylonian revival (626–539 BCE) under Nabopolassar and Nebuchadnezzar II restored imperial power. Major works included the Ishtar Gate, processional way, and the Etemenanki ziggurat; the city became a preeminent urban center. Military campaigns reshaped the Levant, including the 586 BCE capture of Jerusalem and deportations. Babylonian scholars advanced mathematics, astral diaries, and omen compendia that influenced Hellenistic science. The empire fell to Cyrus II in 539 BCE, yet Babylon remained a key administrative and religious hub under Achaemenid and later rulers, preserving learned traditions curated by temple communities.

types.name: Bactria
types.description: Bactria arose on the Oxus and Balkh oasis as a Bronze Age urban zone linked to the Bactria–Margiana Archaeological Complex. By the 6th century BCE it formed an Achaemenid satrapy with irrigated agriculture and metalwork of high quality. Alexander took Bactria in 329–327 BCE and founded colonies. The Greco-Bactrian Kingdom emerged in the 3rd–2nd centuries BCE, striking fine coinage and building cities such as Ai Khanum. Hellenistic rule blended with Iranian and Indian currents and pushed into the Indus. In the 2nd century BCE Yuezhi migrations reshaped the region and led to the Kushan Empire. Bactra (Balkh) remained a key node for trade and Buddhist transmission toward the Tarim and China. The region’s canals, urban craft traditions, and mixed elite culture set the template for later Transoxian centers that Sogdian merchants and Islamic dynasties would inherit.

types.name: Baghdad Vilayet
types.description:
The Baghdad Vilayet emerged under the Ottoman Vilayet Law of 1864, formalized in 1869 from the earlier Baghdad Eyalet. It covered the Tigris corridor around Baghdad, with sanjaks such as Baghdad, Karbala, and Diwaniya; Basra and Mosul were administered separately. Tanzimat reforms introduced cadastral surveys, conscription, provincial councils, and new courts. Midhat Pasha’s governorship (1869–1872) promoted telegraph lines, steam navigation on the Tigris, agricultural colonization, and attempts to regularize tribal taxation. Infrastructure projects, including canal repair and the Hindiyya barrage works, aimed to control flooding and expand cultivation.

By the late nineteenth century, European consuls, missionary schools, and Ottoman-German rail ambitions increased external influence. Ottoman authority fluctuated beyond the river towns, where sheikhly networks mediated state power. During the First World War, British-Indian forces advanced from the Gulf, occupied Baghdad in 1917, and dismantled Ottoman administration. The vilayet framework gave way to British military rule and, soon, to the Mandate-era consolidation of an Iraqi state.

types.name: Ban Chiang
types.description:
Ban Chiang is a prehistoric archaeological culture centered on the Khorat Plateau of northeastern Thailand, with its type-site in Udon Thani Province. Occupation spans the Late Neolithic through the Iron Age, roughly 1500 BCE to the early centuries CE. Excavations reveal early wet rice agriculture, domesticated cattle and pigs, and distinctive red painted ceramics. Mortuary assemblages include shell and stone beads, bronze ornaments, and socketed tools, indicating skilled casting and household metalworking.

Bronze appears by the second to first millennium BCE, followed by iron. Local production used bivalve molds and alloy recipes suited to ornaments and utilitarian blades. Exchange networks linked Ban Chiang communities to the Mekong basin and coastal routes. Materials such as cowrie, marine shell, and exotic stones reached inland cemeteries. Funerary practice shifted over time from flexed to extended burials with rich grave goods. The Ban Chiang sequence documents the emergence of village complexity in Mainland Southeast Asia and a durable technological base later societies inherited.

types.name: Bantu
types.description:
Bantu-speaking communities expanded from the Nigeria–Cameroon borderlands into the Congo Basin between the first millennium BCE and the first millennium CE. They carried iron smelting, woodworking, and farming systems based on yams, oil palm, and, later, banana and plantain. In the forests they founded riverine villages, used dugout canoes for transport, and practiced shifting cultivation with iron hoes and axes that opened mosaics of fields and fallows.
By the late first millennium CE, stable lineage-based chiefdoms emerged. Local pottery traditions and iron industries spread along tributaries of the Congo River. Exchange linked farmers with autochthonous foragers such as the Mbuti through clientage and reciprocity. Copper, salt, raffia cloth, and smoked fish moved on canoe routes. This technological and demographic base enabled the rise of larger polities in both the western lowlands and the south-central lakes region, setting conditions for formations such as Mpemba Kasi and, inland, later Luba statecraft.

types.name: Berbers
types.description:
The Berbers (Amazigh/Imazighen) are the indigenous peoples of the Maghreb, from the Atlantic to the Siwa Oasis. Archaeology traces deep roots through the Iberomaurusian (c. 20,000–9,000 BCE) and Capsian (c. 9,000–4,000 BCE) cultures. A humid Sahara supported pastoralists; after aridification c. 3000 BCE, transhumant herding and oasis settlements expanded. Proto-Berber languages spread across the Atlas and coast. Communities built megaliths, carved rock art, and adopted metallurgy in the first millennium BCE.

Phoenician and Carthaginian contact produced emporia at Lixus, Tingis, and Sala. Berber chieftains formed kingdoms such as Numidia and Mauretania, known for cavalry and light infantry. Caravan routes linked oases across the Sahara. Libyco-Berber scripts appeared, and elites engaged in Mediterranean trade. Religious life blended local cults with Punic and later Roman forms. These social and economic structures underpinned the rise of classical Mauretania and framed the later Islamic conquests and dynasties.

types.name: Brazil
types.description:
Portugal established a colony in 1500. The sugar economy, Indigenous slavery, and the Atlantic slave trade structured the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Dutch occupations in the Northeast (1630–1654) catalyzed fortification and sugar innovation. Gold discoveries in Minas Gerais after the 1690s shifted wealth inland and spurred roads and towns. Pombaline reforms tightened metropolitan control. The court’s transfer to Rio de Janeiro in 1808 opened ports and institutions. Independence came in 1822 under an empire that expanded by coffee, railways, and immigration. Slavery ended in 1888; the Republic followed in 1889.
The twentieth century brought Vargas-era industrial policy, Petrobras and steel, Brasília’s construction, and military rule (1964–1985). Democracy returned with the 1988 Constitution. The Real Plan (1994) stabilized inflation. Growth in the 2000s rode commodities, agribusiness, and Embraer’s aerospace. Corruption probes, recession, and polarized politics marked the 2010s. Contemporary Brazil is a G20 economy with deep inequality and world-scale biodiversity. Pre-salt oil, biofuels, and fintech sit beside Amazon conservation and Indigenous land demarcation debates. Elections in the 2020s reset climate and social policy while keeping fiscal constraints and infrastructure needs at the center.

types.name: Britain
types.description:
Formed in 1707, the Kingdom of Great Britain unified England and Scotland; in 1801 it became the United Kingdom with Ireland. Rapid industrialization from the late eighteenth century created coal, iron, and textile heartlands, powered by steam. Engineers and entrepreneurs built canals, railways, and global shipping networks. Naval strength underpinned victories against Napoleonic France and secured far‑flung trade. Parliament reformed representation, expanded the franchise, and abolished the slave trade (1807) and slavery (1833).

In the twentieth century, Britain fought two world wars, developed radar and codebreaking, and founded the welfare state and National Health Service. Decolonization after 1945 reshaped global ties; the Commonwealth offered a new framework. Immigration from Europe, the Caribbean, South Asia, and Africa altered society and culture. Devolution created legislatures in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, where the 1998 Good Friday Agreement ended most conflict. After joining the European Communities in 1973, the UK left the EU in 2020. Today Britain is a service‑led economy with strengths in finance, life sciences, and creative industries, facing challenges of productivity, regional inequality, and constitutional debate.

types.name: Bulgaria
types.description:
The Bulgarians formed a medieval state south of the Danube in 681 under Khan Asparuh, after alliances of Bulgar groups with Slavic communities. The First Bulgarian Empire challenged Byzantium for centuries, winning recognition and territory. Khan Krum reformed law and administration. Christianization under Boris I (864) anchored the church and diplomacy. Simeon I (893–927) oversaw a cultural apex, with Preslav and Ohrid schools developing Old Church Slavonic and the literary standards that led to the Cyrillic script. Bulgaria became a Slavic liturgical center for Eastern Europe. Old Church Slavonic and Cyrillic spread into Serbia, Rus', and Wallachia.

Byzantium conquered the realm in 1018. The Second Bulgarian Empire arose in 1185 under the Asen brothers, with capitals at Tarnovo and Preslav. Kaloyan defeated the Latin Empire at Adrianople (1205). Ivan Asen II expanded trade along the Danube and the Aegean routes and issued stable coinage. Monastic culture, wall painting, and law codes flourished. Ottoman expansion ended the empire by 1396. Bulgarian elites and church structures survived under Ottoman rule, setting conditions for the later National Revival, schooling in Church Slavonic and modern Bulgarian, and the emergence of autonomous ecclesiastical institutions.

types.name: Buni
types.description:
The Buni culture was an archaeological complex on the north coast of West Java, active from about 400 BCE to the early centuries CE. It is known for fine incised pottery, red‑slipped bowls, pedestalled containers, and spouted jars. Finds of Indian rouletted ware, glass, and carnelian beads indicate sustained trade with South Asia. Settlements clustered along the Citarum delta and the Sunda Strait. People exploited riverine and coastal resources and maintained craft specialization.

Buni ceramics occur at Batujaya, where early brick stupas rose in the 4th–7th centuries CE. The culture bridges late Neolithic and early historic phases in western Java. It provided material and economic bases for later polities, notably Tarumanagara. Its distribution and exchange links foreshadowed the maritime orientation that would define the archipelago. The Buni horizon ends as Indianized courts and script usage took hold, but its production techniques persisted in local pottery traditions.

types.name: Byzantium (Medieval)
types.description: The Eastern Roman Empire, later known as Byzantium, took shape after the division of the empire in 395 CE, with Constantinople as its capital. Under Justinian I (r. 527–565), the empire briefly reconquered Italy, North Africa, and parts of Spain, while codifying Roman law in the Corpus Juris Civilis. Hagia Sophia and other monumental works reflected state patronage of Christianity, which became the official religion. Successive emperors defended long frontiers against Persians, Avars, and early Islamic caliphates, while maintaining grain supply and gold coinage that underpinned Mediterranean trade. The thematic system linked military service with landholding, sustaining defense and rural settlement. Iconoclasm debates of the eighth and ninth centuries reshaped church and politics until the restoration of icons in 843. By the tenth century, under the Macedonian dynasty, Byzantium expanded into the Balkans and eastern Anatolia, while monasteries and scholars preserved classical texts. This period saw the empire remain a dominant Mediterranean power, balancing Roman traditions with a distinct Orthodox Christian identity.

types.name: Byzantium (Renaissance)
types.description: From the eleventh century, Byzantium faced mounting pressures. The defeat at Manzikert in 1071 opened Anatolia to Turkish settlement, reducing the empire’s core revenues. The Komnenian emperors stabilized rule through military reforms and diplomacy, but crusader armies traversed and often disrupted imperial territory. The Fourth Crusade’s capture of Constantinople in 1204 fragmented the empire into successor states, with the Latin Empire in the capital and Greek polities at Nicaea, Epirus, and Trebizond. Nicaea recaptured Constantinople in 1261, but the restored empire struggled with diminished resources, internal aristocratic factions, and rising Ottoman power. By the fourteenth century, civil wars and economic decline left Byzantium dependent on Italian maritime republics for trade and defense. The Ottomans steadily encircled the empire, culminating in the siege of 1453, when Constantinople fell to Mehmed II. Byzantine scholars carried classical learning to Italy, shaping the Renaissance. The empire’s fall ended Roman imperial continuity but laid cultural and religious foundations inherited by Greece and Eastern Orthodoxy.

types.name: Caledonia
types.description: Caledonia was the Roman name for northern Britain beyond the Forth–Clyde isthmus. It encompassed diverse Iron Age communities, including the Caledonii and Maeatae. Settlement was dispersed, with hillforts, crannogs, and brochs in some regions. Agriculture, hunting, and metalworking sustained small-scale polities linked by kin and alliance. Contact with Rome intensified in the first and second centuries CE. Agricola’s campaign and the battle of Mons Graupius (c. 83) entered Roman literature, though direct control proved brief. The Antonine Wall marked the northern limit of sustained Roman garrisoning; Hadrian’s Wall remained the longer frontier. Trade moved across the borderlands despite conflict. Archaeology indicates long continuity in material culture, along with adoption of selected Roman goods. Latin and Roman administration never took hold. By Late Antiquity, power coalesced in larger confederations that would later be known from external sources as Pictish. The Roman withdrawal from Britain left the region independent, culturally distinct, and in contact with Ireland and Scandinavia.

types.name: Canada
types.description:
Canada formed through French and British imperial phases and later federation. New France grew from 16th–18th century fisheries and the St. Lawrence fur trade, built on alliances with Innu, Algonquin, Wendat, and later Cree networks. Britain gained the colony in 1760; the Quebec Act and Loyalist migrations shaped early institutions. Confederation in 1867 joined Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia, followed by westward expansion, the Canadian Pacific Railway, and treaty-making tied to prairie settlement. The Indian Act and residential schools imposed coercive assimilation.
Canada developed parliamentary autonomy through the Statute of Westminster (1931), fought in both World Wars, and patriated its Constitution with the Charter of Rights (1982). Multicultural and bilingual policies, the creation of Nunavut (1999), and court decisions on Aboriginal rights reframed governance. The Truth and Reconciliation Commission (2015) and UNDRIP implementation guide current policy. Today Canada is a G7 economy balancing resource development, climate commitments, and immigration with Indigenous self-government and land claims involving Haudenosaunee, Algonquin, Cree, and many others.

types.name: Caral-Supe
types.description: Caral-Supe, also known as the Norte Chico civilization, flourished in the Supe and adjacent valleys of coastal Peru c. 3000–1800 BCE. It developed one of the earliest urban traditions in the Americas. Major centers such as Caral had platform mounds, sunken circular plazas, and formal residential zones. The economy combined irrigated agriculture with intensive fishing supported by cotton nets. Cotton and food moved between coastal and inland communities through stable exchange networks. Monumental building used shicra bag fill and well planned terraces. Flutes and other instruments attest to organized ritual. Knotted strings found on site may indicate early record-keeping. Long-distance items such as marine shells and exotic stones circulated. Although ceramics were absent, textile production and irrigation engineering were advanced. Caral-Supe established enduring Andean patterns of communal labor, canal management, and valley-centered polities that later cultures on the south coast and highlands adapted to local environments.

types.name: Carib
types.description:
Cariban-speaking groups expanded across the Orinoco basin, Guianas, and Lesser Antilles between roughly 1000 and 1500 CE, with enclaves extending into what is now Colombia. In the Andean foothills and intermontane valleys, Carib-affiliated peoples such as the Pijao and Panche contested frontiers with Chibchan and Arawakan neighbors and later with Spaniards. They excelled at riverine mobility, large dugout canoes, and cassava processing, using griddles, presses, and detoxification techniques that supported populous villages.
Contact-era conflicts were intense in the Magdalena and Tolima regions. Spanish campaigns in the 16th and 17th centuries, disease, and missionization fragmented many polities, though some lowland Cariban communities endured in the Amazonian margins (e.g., Carijona). Carib warfare, exchange networks, and botanical knowledge—curare preparation, fiber weaving, featherwork—shaped frontier dynamics into the colonial period and left enduring cultural enclaves that survive in contemporary Colombia.

types.name: Carthage
types.description: Carthage emerged from the Phoenician colonial sphere into an independent thalassocracy by the sixth century BCE. Centered on the Gulf of Tunis, it controlled maritime routes, agrarian hinterlands, and a chain of ports from North Africa to Iberia and Sardinia. A mixed constitution balanced suffetes, councils, and popular assemblies. Naval power and commercial treaties underpinned its reach. The Barcid family expanded in Iberia after 237 BCE. Carthaginian agronomy was advanced; Mago’s agricultural treatise was later prized by Romans. Monumental harbors, coinage, and urban planning marked its capital. Religious life featured Punic deities and sanctuaries; scholarship debates the Tophet’s function. Conflict with Greek cities in Sicily culminated in long wars with Rome. The Second Punic War saw Hannibal’s campaign in Italy. Defeat in 202 and destruction in 146 BCE ended the state, but Punic culture persisted under Roman Africa, which recycled Carthage’s strategic site.

types.name: Castille
types.description:
Castille emerged from a Leonese frontier county into an independent kingdom by the eleventh century. Its institutions—fueros, hermandades, and the Mesta (1273)—structured settlement, security, and transhumant pastoralism. Castilian forces captured Toledo in 1085 and, after the union with León in 1230, advanced to Cordoba (1236) and Seville (1248). Alfonso X promoted the Siete Partidas, astronomical and historical compilations, and chancery use of Castilian, which consolidated a royal legal and literary tradition.
The late medieval kingdom balanced powerful towns, a tax-negotiating Cortes, and a landed nobility. Crisis in the fourteenth century gave way to institutional consolidation. The dynastic union of Isabella of Castille and Ferdinand of Aragon in 1469 linked crowns while preserving separate laws. Granada fell in 1492, and transatlantic ventures began the same year. Castille provided fiscal capacity, manpower, language, and legal frameworks that became central to the composite Spanish Monarchy and its Atlantic empire.

types.name: Celts
types.description:
The Celts were diverse Iron Age peoples of central and western Europe, rooted in Late Bronze Age traditions. The Hallstatt culture (c. 800–450 BCE) and La Tène culture (c. 450–50 BCE) define their archaeology. They farmed mixed crops and livestock, mined salt and iron, and maintained long-distance trade networks that linked the Atlantic to the Mediterranean. Hillforts and oppida dominated key landscapes. Metalworkers produced fine weapons, harness, and personal ornaments. Chariotry, clientage, and warrior elites shaped society. Druids maintained oral law and ritual.

Celtic groups expanded into Iberia, Gaul, Britain, Ireland, northern Italy, the Balkans, and Anatolia, where Galatia formed. They interacted with Greeks, Etruscans, and Romans as traders and mercenaries. Many communities minted coinage and adopted writing via Greek and Latin scripts. Roman conquest transformed most continental regions, but languages and traditions endured in Ireland, Britain, and Armorica. In Gaul, these foundations framed the later history of the Gauls.

types.name: Chile (Enlightenment)
types.description:
During the Enlightenment and late colonial era, c. 1700–1825, Mapuche polities maintained de facto sovereignty through diplomacy and commerce. Regular parlamentos, including Negrete (1726) and subsequent assemblies, set terms for peace, trade, and mission activity. Mapuche elites expanded a cattle and horse economy tied to markets in Concepción, Valdivia, and across the Andes. Firearms, metal tools, and textiles circulated widely, while kin alliances knit together butalmapu-level politics.

Bourbon officials sought tighter control with forts and roads, yet relied on negotiation after each campaign. The Jesuit expulsion in 1767 altered mission networks but not frontier autonomy. After 1810, republican Chile continued treaty-making, most notably the Parlamento of Tapihue (1825), which recognized Mapuche territorial integrity. Increasing settler pressure and state colonization plans in the 1840s–1850s eroded this balance, setting conditions for the nineteenth-century occupation of Araucanía and the reduction of Mapuche lands into scattered reservations.

types.name: Chile (Modern)
types.description:
Chile emerged as an independent republic in 1818 after the Wars of Independence led by Bernardo O'Higgins and José de San Martín. A stable conservative order in the mid-19th century built institutions, codified law, and expanded education. Expansion southward culminated in the occupation of Araucanía (1861–1883), which dismantled Mapuche autonomy. Victory in the War of the Pacific (1879–1883) added nitrate-rich provinces, financing railways, ports, and urban growth. The parliamentary republic (1891–1925) faced labor unrest and cycles of boom and bust.

The 20th century brought copper dominance, social reform, and political polarization. The state nationalized major copper mines in 1971. A military coup in 1973 installed Augusto Pinochet’s dictatorship, marked by repression and market liberalization. Democracy returned in 1990 with a negotiated transition and sustained growth under export-led policies. Since 2006, student movements and the 2019 social uprising have pressed for equity and institutional change. Constitutional reform efforts advanced but faced repeated plebiscite setbacks in 2022 and 2023. Today Chile is an OECD member with strong macroeconomic management, a leading copper and lithium sector, and ambitious renewable energy plans, while debates over pensions, inequality, and indigenous rights continue.

types.name: China
types.description: The Republic of China replaced the Qing in 1912. After a warlord period, the Nationalist government reunified much of the country in 1928. The Second Sino‑Japanese War (1937–1945) devastated industry and population. Civil war resumed, and in 1949 the People’s Republic of China (PRC) was founded on the mainland, while the ROC continued on Taiwan. Early PRC policies included land reform, collectivization, and Soviet‑style industrialization. The Great Leap Forward caused severe famine, and the Cultural Revolution disrupted education and governance. From 1978, reform and opening introduced market mechanisms, Special Economic Zones, and foreign investment. Rapid industrialization, urbanization, and infrastructure expansion followed, including high‑speed rail and large‑scale energy projects. China joined the WTO in 2001 and advanced in spaceflight, digital platforms, and manufacturing. Recent decades brought poverty reduction, environmental policy shifts, carbon‑reduction pledges, and global economic initiatives such as the Belt and Road. China is a leading world economy with significant scientific output and military modernization. Taiwan developed separately with industrial growth and democratic institutions, shaping ongoing cross‑strait dynamics.

types.name: Chinchorro
types.description:
The Chinchorro were preceramic fisher-hunter-gatherers of the Atacama Desert coast, active c. 7000–1500 BCE. They occupied shores from southern Peru to northern Chile, clustering near Arica and the Camarones Valley. Their economy relied on maritime foraging: fish, shellfish, sea mammals, and seabirds. They used reed rafts, nets of plant fiber, harpoons, and bone hooks. Camps and cemeteries show long-term coastal settlement and seasonal mobility.

The Chinchorro developed the world’s earliest artificial mummification, beginning before 5000 BCE. Black and red mummy techniques used skin removal, reed supports, clay masks, and mineral pigments. Mortuary care extended to adults, children, and infants, indicating broad social concern. Material exchange with highland groups moved obsidian and pigments along the coast–Andes corridor. The tradition waned after the mid 2nd millennium BCE as new coastal lifeways and later ceramic cultures appeared, but their mortuary innovations shaped the deep cultural record of northern Chile.

types.name: Ciboney
types.description:
The Ciboney, identified by Spanish sources as Guanahatabey in western Cuba, were preceramic foragers whose lifeways span the Caribbean Archaic Age into early colonial times. Archaeology places their core in Pinar del Río, Isla de la Juventud, and adjacent coasts. They lived in small, mobile bands, exploited marine shallows, and left extensive shell middens and cave occupations. Toolkits were dominated by lithic flakes and shell implements. Pottery and intensive agriculture are absent from their sites.

From the late first millennium BCE, ceramic-bearing agriculturalists of Arawakan origin reached Cuba. In the west the Ciboney persisted in ecological niches and maintained distinct traditions. Some groups were absorbed by incoming villagers; others retreated to less accessible coasts. At European contact they still occupied parts of western Cuba, but disease, displacement, and labor drafts led to their rapid decline. Their deep coastal knowledge informed later Cuban subsistence and place-names.

types.name: Colombia
types.description:
Colonial New Granada emerged from the conquest of Muisca and neighboring polities after 1537. The Audiencia of Bogotá and later the Viceroyalty structured extraction of gold, salt, and agricultural surpluses while integrating Andean, Caribbean, and Pacific routes first built by indigenous networks. Bourbon reforms, the 1781 Comuneros Revolt, and Atlantic ideas fostered crisis. Independence wars (1810–1819) created Gran Colombia, which fragmented by 1830. Nineteenth-century Colombia cycled through centralist and federalist constitutions, civil wars, and coffee-led export growth. The 1886 constitution consolidated a central state; the Thousand Days’ War (1899–1902) and Panama’s separation followed.
Twentieth-century Colombia urbanized and diversified into coffee, oil, coal, and manufacturing. La Violencia (1948–1958) and the National Front shaped mid-century politics. From the 1960s, insurgencies and drug cartels drove internal conflict. The 1991 Constitution expanded rights and decentralization. A 2016 accord with FARC reduced conflict, while ELN talks continue. Today Colombia is a middle-income democracy with major biodiversity, expanding infrastructure on both coasts, and growing cultural industries. Ongoing challenges include rural reform, substitution of illicit economies, and implementing transitional justice.

types.name: Congo
types.description:
The modern state of Congo descends from the Congo Free State (1885–1908), a personal colony of Leopold II marked by violent rubber extraction, and the Belgian Congo (1908–1960), which built railways, mining centers in Katanga, and ports at Matadi, Léopoldville, and Elisabethville. Independence in 1960 brought the Congo Crisis, with Katanga and South Kasai secessions, UN intervention, and the assassination of Patrice Lumumba. Joseph-Désiré Mobutu seized power in 1965, renamed the country Zaire in 1971, promoted state corporatism, and presided over economic decline.
In 1996–1997 the AFDL toppled Mobutu. The Second Congo War (1998–2003) drew in multiple states and armed groups. A peace process led to elections and the Democratic Republic of the Congo name. Since 2006 the country has pursued reconstruction while facing persistent conflict in the east. The DRC is now the world’s leading source of cobalt and a major copper producer, holds vast rainforest and hydropower potential at Inga, and sustains major cultural industries such as Congolese rumba. Governance and security reforms continue amid regional diplomacy and conservation initiatives.

types.name: Cree
types.description:
The Cree (Nêhiyawak, including Swampy, Woodland, and Plains divisions) are an Algonquian-speaking people whose early heartland lay around James and Hudson Bays. After 1670, ties with the Hudson’s Bay Company accelerated westward expansion as trappers, hunters, and middlemen. Plains Cree adopted horses and participated in bison economies and pemmican trade, allied at times with Assiniboine and Métis and contending with Blackfoot nations. James Evans adapted syllabics for Cree in the 1840s, enabling rapid literacy.
Numbered Treaties (notably 4, 6, 8) and the reserve and residential school systems reshaped communities in the 19th–20th centuries. The 1885 crisis involved leaders such as Big Bear. Modern agreements mark a major turn: the James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement (1975) and subsequent accords created the Cree Nation Government and regional co-management in Eeyou Istchee. Today Cree nations span Quebec to Alberta, assert language vitality, and negotiate roles in forestry, mining, and energy. Court-backed rights, impact-benefit agreements, and cultural education frame contemporary governance.

types.name: Cuba (Modern)
types.description:
Modern Cuba emerged from protracted wars of independence. The Ten Years’ War (1868–78) weakened slavery and colonial authority. The War of 1895, led by José Martí, Máximo Gómez, and Antonio Maceo, ended with U.S. intervention in 1898. A republic formed in 1902 under the Platt Amendment, repealed in 1934. Sugar monoculture, U.S. investment, and cyclical crises shaped the early republic. Political upheavals culminated in Batista’s dominance and the 1959 revolutionary victory.

After 1959 the state nationalized key sectors, carried out agrarian reform, and ran a nationwide literacy campaign. Alignment with the USSR brought industrial aid, oil, and a guaranteed sugar market. Cuba deployed troops and doctors abroad and joined the Non-Aligned Movement. The 1990s Special Period followed Soviet collapse, with severe contraction and limited market openings. The 2010s saw gradual economic reforms, a U.S. rapprochement (2014–16), and renewed sanctions thereafter. A new constitution (2019) recognized private enterprise; MSMEs expanded from 2021 amid currency unification, pandemic shocks, and energy shortages. Biotech developed notable vaccines and therapies, tourism recovered unevenly, and emigration rose. The one-party system endures, with periodic protests and ongoing adjustment to global and regional shifts.

types.name: Cuba (Renaissance)
types.description: Spanish conquest of Cuba began in 1511 under Diego Velázquez, who founded Baracoa, Santiago, and Havana as administrative and military centers. Indigenous communities were rapidly reduced by disease, forced labor, and resettlement, though survivors contributed crops, skills, and local knowledge to colonial society. By the mid-sixteenth century, Cuba served as a provisioning and transit point for fleets bound between Spain and the Americas, with Havana’s harbor fortified to guard treasure convoys. African slavery expanded to sustain cattle ranching, tobacco, and later sugar cultivation, producing a plantation economy and maroon communities in frontier zones. Repeated corsair raids prompted fortifications such as El Morro, while Havana grew into a key Atlantic port. By the eighteenth century, intensified sugar and tobacco exports tied Cuba more closely to global markets, and large slave imports altered demographics. Bourbon reforms strengthened defenses and administration, while creole elites, smallholders, and enslaved populations shaped a society that bridged Indigenous, African, and European influences on the eve of the independence wars.

types.name: Damascus Eyalet
types.description:
The Damascus Eyalet was an Ottoman province from 1516 until mid-19th century administrative reforms. After the conquest from the Mamluks, the Porte confirmed urban notables and sufi networks while installing timar-holders and Janissary garrisons. The governor (beylerbeyi) led the annual Hajj caravan to Mecca, provisioning routes across the Syrian Desert. Taxes were farmed to local ayan. Craft guilds and caravan trade linked Damascus with Aleppo, Hama, and the ports of Sidon and Acre.

Seventeenth-century turbulence, Bedouin attacks, and Celali-era migrations altered settlement. In 1831–1840 Egyptian occupation under Muhammad Ali imposed conscription and cadastral surveys. After 1840 Ottoman control resumed. Tanzimat laws reorganized land tenure and courts. The 1864 Vilayet Law replaced the eyalet with the Syria Vilayet centered at Damascus. By the late 19th century railways and steam navigation shifted commerce toward Beirut and Haifa, but Damascus remained a pilgrimage hub and an administrative capital that fed into the late Ottoman reform era.

types.name: Edo
types.description: The Edo period (Tokugawa shogunate), 1603–1868, secured long internal peace after civil war. The shogun ruled from Edo and controlled daimyo through alternate attendance and castle laws. A formal order of samurai, peasants, artisans, and merchants structured society. Agricultural expansion, village compacts, and flood control raised yields. Edo, Osaka, and Kyoto became major cities. Commercialization created national markets, rice exchanges, and proto-industry in textiles, paper, and sake. Cultural life grew in kabuki, bunraku, haiku, and ukiyo-e. Foreign contacts narrowed under sakoku, yet Dutch trade at Nagasaki sustained rangaku in medicine and astronomy. Fiscal strains, famines, and protests stressed the regime. Reform cycles alternated between austerity and growth. Western gunboat diplomacy from 1853 forced treaty ports and exposed political rifts. The shogunate collapsed in 1868, opening the path to a modernizing imperial government.

types.name: Egypt
types.description:
After the Ottoman conquest, Egypt remained an imperial province where Mamluk beys contended for power. The French expedition (1798–1801) disrupted this order. Muhammad Ali seized authority in 1805, building a conscript army, schools, and factories. Cotton monoculture, irrigation, and monopolies funded expansion into Sudan, the Hijaz, and Syria until European pressure curtailed ambitions in 1840. The Khedivate (from 1867) pursued railways and the Suez Canal (opened 1869), but debt triggered British occupation in 1882. Nationalist agitation led to nominal independence in 1922 and a limited constitutional monarchy.

The Free Officers ended the monarchy in 1952. Under Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egypt nationalized the canal, built the Aswan High Dam, and advanced land reform and import substitution; defeat in 1967 reshaped policy. Anwar Sadat won ground in 1973, signed peace with Israel, and opened the economy. Hosni Mubarak oversaw stability and gradual privatization amid demographic growth. The 2011 uprising led to a brief Islamist presidency and the rise of Abdel Fattah el-Sisi in 2013. Contemporary Egypt emphasizes state-led infrastructure, energy projects, and security partnerships, while managing Nile water diplomacy and a diversified, service-led economy anchored by the canal and remittances.

types.name: Elam
types.description:
Elam was a Bronze and early Iron Age civilization in southwestern Iran, centered on Susa and Anshan. It emerged by the late third millennium BCE and interacted with Sumer, Akkad, and Babylon through trade, diplomacy, and war. Rulers such as Shutruk-Nahhunte campaigned in Mesopotamia and carried prestigious monuments to Susa. Elamite kingship often took a federated form, and the Elamite language maintained its own script traditions, including Linear Elamite and later Akkadian cuneiform.

Elam built monumental complexes such as Chogha Zanbil, advanced bronze metallurgy, and produced fine textiles. Despite Assyrian and Babylonian pressures, Elamite polities persisted into the sixth century BCE. Cyrus II incorporated Elam in 539 BCE; Elamite remained an administrative language of the early Achaemenid chancery. Elamite religious, artistic, and bureaucratic elements helped shape the emerging imperial Persian order.

types.name: England
types.description:
Under the Plantagenets, the Kingdom of England evolved durable institutions. Magna Carta (1215) constrained royal authority. Common law, juries, and the eyre circuit structured justice. Parliament emerged from thirteenth‑century assemblies of nobles, prelates, and towns. War with France shaped taxation, the navy, and strategy during the Hundred Years’ War. The Black Death transformed demography and labor. The Wars of the Roses (1455–1487) ended with Tudor consolidation.

The Tudors centralized rule and broke with Rome. The English Reformation created a national church and redirected monastic wealth. Maritime ventures expanded under Elizabeth I, laying bases for later empire. The Stuarts faced fiscal and religious conflict, producing civil wars, a republic, and restoration. The Glorious Revolution of 1688 secured parliamentary supremacy and a Bill of Rights. Scientific and literary culture flourished around the Royal Society and the printing trade. In 1707, union with Scotland created the Kingdom of Great Britain.

types.name: Ethiopia
types.description:
Modern Ethiopia took shape under Tewodros II, who pursued centralization, new armaments, and judicial change. Yohannes IV defended the state against Egyptian and Mahdist wars. Menelik II expanded the empire to the south and east, founded Addis Ababa, and began modernization. In 1896 Ethiopian forces defeated Italy at Adwa, securing international recognition and treaty revision. Haile Selassie advanced state reform and issued constitutions in 1931 and 1955. Italy invaded in 1935. Occupation lasted to 1941, when Allied operations and Ethiopian resistance restored independence.

Postwar policy combined development with assertive diplomacy; Addis Ababa became headquarters of the Organization of African Unity in 1963. Economic strain and unrest culminated in the 1974 revolution. The Derg abolished the monarchy, nationalized land, and fought insurgencies; repression and famine followed. The EPRDF seized power in 1991 and created a federal republic. Eritrea achieved independence in 1993. Growth accelerated in the 2000s, with major infrastructure and the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam. Since 2018, political opening and conflict have coincided, including peace with Eritrea and the 2020–2022 Tigray war. Ethiopia remains central to African Union affairs.

types.name: Etruscan
types.description:
The Etruscan civilization developed in Etruria, between the Arno and Tiber, from the late Bronze Age and early Iron Age (c. 900–500 BCE). It formed a network of city-states organized into a loose league, with urban planning, monumental necropolises, and elaborate religious rites. Etruscan elites controlled metal resources and maritime trade with Greeks and Phoenicians. They pioneered advanced drainage and terracing, road building, and the arch in construction. Artistic production included bronze casting, terracotta sculpture, and bucchero pottery. Their alphabet, adapted from Greek, shaped early Italic literacy.

Etruscan dynasts influenced early Rome; several Roman kings had Etruscan names, and key Roman institutions drew on Etruscan ritual. The civilization declined from the fifth century BCE due to pressure from Gauls, Syracuse, and Carthage at sea, and the steady expansion of Rome on land. By the first century BCE, Etruscan cities were incorporated into the Roman state, yet religious practices, engineering methods, and artistic motifs continued in Roman Italy.

types.name: France (Kingdom)
types.description: From the later Valois and Bourbon dynasties, France consolidated as a centralized monarchy. The sixteenth century saw both Renaissance culture and violent conflict between Catholics and Huguenots, ending with the Edict of Nantes (1598). Bourbon rulers strengthened fiscal systems, standing armies, and overseas trade. Under Louis XIII and his minister Richelieu, France expanded its role in the Thirty Years’ War, while Louis XIV embodied absolutism at Versailles, waged wars of expansion, and enforced Catholic uniformity after revoking the Edict of Nantes. His successors inherited a complex bureaucracy, colonial possessions in the Americas and Asia, and mounting debt from near-constant warfare. Eighteenth-century intellectual life was shaped by the Enlightenment, as salons and publications debated reason, rights, and state reform. Fiscal crisis, social tensions, and defeat in the Seven Years’ War sharpened calls for change. By 1789, monarchy and aristocracy faced collapse, as revolution overthrew the Bourbon state and laid foundations for modern France.

types.name: France (Modern)
types.description:
Modern France was forged by the Revolution and Napoleonic reforms. The First Republic mobilized mass armies and recast law and property. Napoleon Bonaparte centralized administration through prefectures, stabilized finance with the Banque de France, and promulgated the Civil Code. After 1815 the Restoration and July Monarchy balanced crown and public life. The 1848 revolution created universal male suffrage and the Second Republic. The Second Empire accelerated railways and urban redesign under Haussmann.

Defeat in 1870 created the Third Republic. It built secular schools, expanded colonial rule in Africa and Indochina, and faced the Dreyfus Affair. France endured the Western Front in 1914–1918 and emerged victorious but scarred. In 1940 the state collapsed before Germany. Vichy governed part of the country while the Resistance and Free French fought on. Liberation in 1944 restored republican institutions and social insurance.

The Fourth Republic rebuilt the economy, launched European integration, and struggled with decolonization. The Fifth Republic from 1958 strengthened the presidency and developed independent nuclear forces. Postwar industry produced the TGV, Airbus, and Ariane. Since the 1990s France has deepened EU ties, adopted the euro, and faced globalization, migration, and terrorism. A nuclear sector shapes energy policy. Culture, science, and heritage remain central to national influence.

types.name: Franks
types.description: The Franks arose along the Rhine in late antiquity, serving as federates under Rome before establishing rule in Gaul. Clovis I unified much of northern Gaul by 511 and allied the dynasty with Catholic bishops. Merovingian power relied on royal estates and assemblies but waned as mayors of the palace dominated. Charles Martel restructured cavalry levies, and his son Pippin III claimed the crown in 751 with papal backing. Under Charlemagne, the Carolingian Empire stretched across western Europe, promoted the Carolingian Renaissance, and fostered administrative literacy. The empire fractured in the ninth century, with West Francia forming the basis of the French kingdom. Capetian kings from 987 gradually extended their domain through conquest and marriage, while Gothic cathedrals and universities marked cultural life. Conflicts with England culminated in the Hundred Years’ War, ending in 1453 with French victory. By the sixteenth century, France confronted internal religious wars, Habsburg rivalry, and participation in the Thirty Years’ War, emerging as a leading continental power.

types.name: Ganden Phodrang
types.description:
The Ganden Phodrang government was established in 1642 when the Fifth Dalai Lama, backed by the Khoshut ruler Güshi Khan, unified Ü and Tsang under a Lhasa-based regime. The Potala Palace and large Gelug monasteries became administrative and scholastic hubs. After Dzungar incursions, Qing forces intervened (1720), installed ambans, and issued regulatory codes in 1751 and 1793 that defined executive roles, tribute, and frontier defense. The state maintained diplomatic and military activity, including wars with Nepal and the 1904 British expedition. With the Qing collapse in 1911–1912, the 13th Dalai Lama reasserted control, introduced a small standing army, minted currency and stamps, and attempted fiscal and legal reforms.

Modernizing efforts remained limited in scale. In 1950 PLA forces entered eastern Tibet; the 17-Point Agreement (1951) altered the framework of authority. The 1959 Lhasa uprising ended the government’s rule in Tibet, and leadership continued in exile. The Ganden Phodrang’s legacy includes stable legal-administrative forms, a broad monastic education system, and advances in arts, architecture, and medicine.

types.name: Gauls
types.description:
The Gauls were Celtic-speaking societies of Iron Age and early Roman Gaul, spanning much of present-day France, Belgium, and parts of Switzerland and northern Italy. Tribal polities such as the Aedui, Arverni, and Sequani formed alliances and rivalries. Oppida like Bibracte and Avaricum anchored craft production and exchange. Trade through Massalia moved wine, ceramics, and metals. Local mints issued coinage. Artisans excelled in smithing, glassworking, and fine bronzes.

Roman expansion reshaped the region. Julius Caesar campaigned from 58 to 50 BCE, defeating Vercingetorix at Alesia after setbacks at Gergovia. Southern Gallia Narbonensis had already been organized as a province. Under the empire, roads, cities, and sanctuaries multiplied. Lugdunum became a major administrative and minting center. Latin spread while Gallo-Roman identities formed. Christianity took hold by the third and fourth centuries. Prosperous provincial elites integrated into imperial structures, creating the social and economic base that the Franks would later inherit.

types.name: Germanic
types.description:
The Germanic peoples emerged from the Nordic Bronze Age and early Iron Age cultures of Scandinavia and northern Germany. By the first millennium BCE, the Jastorf culture marked a coherent material horizon and a distinct Proto-Germanic language community. Longhouses, ironworking, and boat use supported mixed farming and maritime trade. The amber routes linked the Baltic to the Mediterranean.

Contact with Celts and then Rome intensified from the second century BCE. Groups such as the Cimbri and the Teutones moved south and fought Rome. Roman authors, including Tacitus, described social structures based on assemblies, warrior elites, and customary law. The runic script appeared in the second century CE. In the Roman and Migration periods, Germanic groups expanded across continental Europe and Britain. These movements produced new identities, including Goths, Vandals, and Saxons. Their political experiments, legal customs, and martial skills shaped Late Antiquity and laid foundations for early medieval polities.

types.name: Germany
types.description:
The German Empire (1871) unified diverse states under Prussian leadership. Rapid industrialization followed, centered in the Ruhr and Saxony. Bismarck built social insurance and balanced great-power diplomacy. Defeat in 1918 ended the monarchy. The Weimar Republic saw cultural innovation and severe crises. The Nazi dictatorship seized power in 1933, launched aggressive war, and carried out genocide. Germany’s defeat in 1945 brought occupation and partition.

In 1949 the Federal Republic of Germany formed in the west and the German Democratic Republic in the east. West Germany experienced the Wirtschaftswunder, anchored itself in NATO and the European Communities, and pursued social market policies. Ostpolitik reduced tensions. The 1989 revolution and 1990 unification restored a single state. Germany adopted the euro, hosts the European Central Bank, and drives EU policy. It built an export economy based on engineering, chemicals, and autos. Recent decades feature the Energiewende, digitalization efforts, and a security “Zeitenwende” after 2022. Germany is a federal parliamentary democracy with a central role in European integration.

types.name: Ghana
types.description:
The Ghana Empire (Wagadu) emerged among Soninke speakers in the upper Senegal–Niger region by the sixth century CE. Its kings, styled Kaya Maghan, ruled from a capital recalled as Koumbi Saleh, a dual town with a royal quarter and a Muslim mercantile quarter. The state taxed trans-Saharan caravans moving gold, salt, and textiles between the Sahel and Maghrib, drawing revenue from the Bambuk goldfields and from market duties.

Islam spread among traders and parts of the court while indigenous law and ritual framed kingship. Cavalry and fortified settlements anchored authority over tributary provinces. Contacts with the Almoravids in the eleventh century were significant, but their role in the empire’s decline is contested. Environmental stress, trade realignments, and pressure from Sosso polities eroded power in the twelfth century. By the early thirteenth century Ghana fragmented, creating the political landscape on which Sundiata and the Mandinka built the Mali Empire.

types.name: Golden Horde
types.description:
The Golden Horde, or Jochid Ulus, arose in the 1240s under Batu Khan after campaigns in the Rus’ lands and the Volga region. Its capitals at Sarai on the lower Volga anchored a steppe–riverine economy that taxed trade between the Black Sea, Central Asia, and the forest zone. The Horde ruled Rus’ principalities through tribute and charters (yarlyks), balancing local elites while maintaining steppe military supremacy. Early rulers allied with the Mamluks against the Ilkhanate; Muslim conversion at the court culminated under Özbeg Khan (r. 1313–1341), who made Islam state religion and stabilized coinage and commerce.
Civil wars after 1359 weakened the polity. Dmitry Donskoy’s victory at Kulikovo (1380) signaled Muscovite resilience, though Tokhtamysh briefly restored authority before Timur’s campaigns (1395) shattered Sarai. The ulus fragmented into successor khanates, including Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea. Its institutions shaped Muscovy’s rise, fiscal practices, and cavalry organization, while Black Sea trade networks persisted under Genoese and later Ottoman influence.

types.name: Goths
types.description:
The Goths formed an East Germanic grouping known archaeologically through the Wielbark culture near the lower Vistula. By the third century CE they moved toward the Black Sea and built the Chernyakhov cultural zone. They organized as Tervingi and Greuthungi and pressed the Roman Danube frontier. The defeat of a Roman army at Adrianople in 378 marked a turning point.

Under Alaric, Visigothic forces entered Italy and sacked Rome in 410. A Visigothic kingdom developed from Toulouse to Hispania and issued the Codex Euricianus. Catholic conversion in 589 integrated Hispania with wider Latin Christendom. The Ostrogoths ruled Italy under Theoderic the Great from Ravenna and balanced Roman administration with Gothic military authority. Justinian’s wars ended their kingdom by 553, though Gothic communities persisted, including in Crimea. Gothic law, foederati arrangements, and mobile heavy cavalry influenced post-Roman statecraft.

types.name: Greece
types.description:
After the fall of Constantinople in 1453, most Greek lands came under Ottoman rule. The empire incorporated Byzantine institutions into its provincial framework, with local notables and the Orthodox Patriarchate mediating imperial authority. Coastal areas experienced pirate raids and Venetian-Ottoman wars, while mountain communities retained partial autonomy. Monasteries preserved learning and traditions, and merchants expanded networks across the Mediterranean and Black Sea. Periodic uprisings, such as the Orlov Revolt (1770), revealed both resistance and the limits of foreign support. The Greek Enlightenment of the late eighteenth century, fostered by diaspora intellectuals, laid foundations for nationalism.

The War of Independence (1821–1829) combined local revolts with international intervention, leading to recognition of the Kingdom of Greece in 1832 under King Otto. Nineteenth-century Greece adopted European legal codes and expanded with the Ionian Islands (1864), Thessaly (1881), and territories gained after the Balkan Wars (1912–1913). Defeat in Asia Minor (1922) brought population exchange with Turkey. Political turbulence followed, including dictatorship, German occupation, and a civil war (1946–1949). Reconstruction, NATO membership (1952), and European integration transformed society. The 1967–1974 military junta collapsed after the Cyprus crisis, ushering in the Third Republic. Greece joined the EU in 1981, adopted the euro in 2001, and weathered the 2009–2018 debt crisis. Today it remains a parliamentary democracy with an economy led by tourism, shipping, and services, active in the Balkans and Eastern Mediterranean.

types.name: Guaraní
types.description:
The Guaraní, a major Tupi-Guarani branch, expanded along the Paraná, Paraguay, and Uruguay river basins between the first millennium CE and European contact. Village clusters practiced intensive horticulture of manioc and maize, complemented by fishing and hunting. River corridors and the Peabiru trail network linked the Atlantic coast to the interior. Prophetic movements seeking the Land Without Evil structured migrations and alliances. Music, long-distance canoe travel, and trade in yerba mate shaped regional influence.
From 1609 the Jesuit reducción system reorganized Guaraní populations into planned towns across the Upper Paraná. These communities developed militias, printed music, schools, and large-scale yerba mate production, forming a powerful frontier society until the 1767 expulsion of the Jesuits and the Guaraní War (1754–56). After imperial partition, Guaraní lands were divided among Brazil, Paraguay, and Argentina. Guaraní remains a national language in Paraguay and a regional lingua franca. Today, Guaraní groups, including the Guarani-Kaiowá, lead land-rights campaigns and cultural revitalization across southern Brazil.

types.name: Gupta
types.description:
The Gupta Dynasty (c. 320–550 CE) consolidated a northern Indian empire under Chandragupta I, Samudragupta, and Chandragupta II. Administration combined hereditary offices with tributary polities. Gold coinage with refined die work circulated among courts and guilds. Sanskrit culture flourished; royal patronage supported poets such as Kalidasa and scholastic centers linked to later Nalanda.

Innovation advanced in mathematics and astronomy. Aryabhata computed pi to notable precision, described trigonometric functions, and modeled planetary motion. Place-value decimal numeration and a dot or small circle for zero are attested in this milieu. Metallurgy achieved high corrosion resistance, exemplified by the Delhi iron pillar. Temple and sculpture styles established durable North Indian canons. From the late fifth century, Huna incursions and regional fragmentation eroded central authority. Gupta political structures dissolved, but artistic and scientific norms persisted in successor states and transregional scholarship.

types.name: Han
types.description: The Han dynasty (206 BCE–220 CE) unified China after the Qin collapse and built a durable imperial framework. Emperor Gaozu established stable institutions; Emperor Wu expanded the realm into the Hexi Corridor, the Tarim Basin, northern Vietnam, and commanderies in Korea, enabling Silk Road exchange. The state adopted Confucian ideology, codified law, standardized coinage, and managed key monopolies on salt and iron. Innovations included papermaking, improved iron metallurgy, the seismograph, hydraulic engineering, and a refined calendar. Historical writing reached a high point with Sima Qian. The dynasty was interrupted by Wang Mang’s Xin regime (9–23 CE) but restored as Eastern Han (25–220). Mounting factionalism, peasant uprisings such as the Yellow Turban revolt, and warlord competition ended Han rule, leading to the Three Kingdoms era. Han administrative norms and cultural synthesis shaped later dynasties.

types.name: Harappan
types.description:
The Harappan, or Indus Valley Civilization, flourished across the Indus and Ghaggar-Hakra systems c. 2600–1900 BCE, with antecedents from c. 3300 BCE. Major urban centers included Mohenjo-daro, Harappa, Dholavira, and Lothal. Cities followed orthogonal street plans, used baked-brick architecture, and maintained covered drainage and standardized weights. Artisans worked copper-bronze, faience, shell, and carnelian. Trade reached across the Arabian Sea to Oman and Mesopotamia; Lothal’s dockyard suggests maritime capacity.

An undeciphered script occurs on seals and tablets. Evidence for palaces or large temples is limited; storage and craft precincts indicate complex urban management. Agriculture produced wheat, barley, millets, and cotton; zebu cattle were prominent. After c. 1900 BCE, urban systems contracted, with regional Late Harappan traditions and population shifts eastward. Aridification and river reorganization are leading explanations for decline. Cultural continuities persisted in craft techniques, weights, and agricultural practices into later northern Indian cultures.

types.name: Hellenic
types.description:
The Hellenic world spans the Archaic, Classical, and Hellenistic eras, c. 800–30 BCE. In the Archaic period Greek city-states formed, adopted the alphabet, and founded colonies from the Black Sea to Iberia. Lawgivers such as Solon and Lycurgus shaped civic orders. Panhellenic sanctuaries at Olympia and Delphi fostered shared cults and competition. Hoplite warfare and naval power evolved.

Classical Greece saw the Persian Wars, the rise of Athenian democracy, and Sparta’s rival league. Architecture and sculpture reached canonical forms; the Parthenon and other works anchored a durable aesthetic. Philosophers including Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle systematized ethics, politics, and natural inquiry. Tragedy and comedy matured, while historians like Herodotus and Thucydides created critical narrative.

Macedon unified Greece; Alexander the Great carried Greek arms and culture across the Near East. Hellenistic kingdoms promoted urbanization, scholarship, and exchange. Koine Greek became a lingua franca. Centers such as Alexandria fostered mathematics, astronomy, and medicine through figures like Euclid, Archimedes, and Eratosthenes. Gradual Roman conquest integrated the Greek world into imperial structures.

types.name: Hittite
types.description:
The Hittite kingdom emerged in central Anatolia in the 17th century BCE and consolidated under the Old and later the New Kingdom with its capital at Hattusa. It developed an advanced bureaucratic state using cuneiform, preserving the earliest extensive Indo-European texts, legal codes, festival records, and diplomatic correspondence. The empire expanded across Anatolia and into northern Syria, administering key cities through viceroyalties at Aleppo and Carchemish. It engaged Egypt as a peer power; the aftermath of the Battle of Kadesh produced one of the earliest surviving international treaties. Fortification architecture, road systems, and state cults supported imperial cohesion.

After about 1200 BCE the central state collapsed amid regional upheaval, climate stress, and external attacks. Neo-Hittite principalities persisted in southeastern Anatolia and Syria. Hittite legal and diplomatic practices influenced later Near Eastern polities, and the archaeological record at Hattusa, with its archives and city walls, remains a primary source for Bronze Age Anatolia.

types.name: Hồng Bàng
types.description:
The Hồng Bàng period denotes the legendary formation of Văn Lang under the Hùng kings, traditionally dated to the late third millennium to the late first millennium BCE. Archaeology anchors this era in the Red River basin through the Phùng Nguyên, Đồng Đậu, Gò Mun, and especially Đông Sơn cultures. Communities practiced intensive wet-rice agriculture, riverine transport, weaving, and bronze metallurgy. Đông Sơn bronze drums and weaponry attest to advanced casting and regional exchange across Lingnan and Island Southeast Asia.

Settlement formed clustered chiefdoms tied by kinship and ritual authority. Stilt houses, embankments, and paddy systems adapted to monsoon hydrology. Oral genealogies later preserved in medieval chronicles linked ruling lineages to sacred landscapes. In the late phase, the polity of Âu Lạc emerged with fortified centers such as Cổ Loa, marking a transition to larger-scale organization. This consolidation set the stage for conflict with the kingdom of Nam Việt under Triệu Đà.

types.name: Hopewell
types.description:
The Hopewell tradition flourished in the Ohio and Great Lakes regions c. 100 BCE–500 CE. Communities built earthen mounds and vast geometric earthworks used for mortuary rites and periodic gatherings. Long-distance exchange moved obsidian from the Rockies, copper from the Great Lakes, mica from Appalachia, and marine shells inland. Dispersed hamlets relied on riverine fisheries, foraging, and small gardens. Craft specialists produced fine ceramics, carved stone pipes, and copper ornaments that circulated within ritual gift systems.
The tradition waned after the 5th century because of social reorganization and climate variability. Its earthworks and travel corridors remained embedded in the landscape. Later Algonquian- and Iroquoian-speaking peoples in the St. Lawrence and upper Great Lakes encountered these sites and reused interior routes that linked forests to the coasts.

types.name: Hun
types.description:
The Hun confederation emerged on the Pontic steppe in the late fourth century CE, rapidly absorbing Alans and pressuring Gothic groups into Roman territory. Using composite bows, disciplined cavalry, and a tributary system, Hunnic leaders exploited the fracture lines of late Roman frontier politics. Under Attila (r. 434–453), they extracted subsidies from Constantinople, campaigned across the Balkans, entered Gaul in 451, and reached northern Italy in 452. The confederation fused Turkic, Iranian, and Germanic elements under a mobile command, supported by skilled horse archers and swift operational marches.
After Attila’s death, internal rivalries and subject revolts broke the union at the Battle of Nedao (454). Although their polity dissolved, the Huns accelerated the Great Migration, transformed Danubian power balances, and spread steppe cavalry techniques and diplomatic practices into Europe. Their political model of overlordship, tribute, and delegated rule foreshadowed later steppe empires.

types.name: Iberian
types.description:
The Iberians occupied the eastern and southeastern coasts and hinterlands of the peninsula from the sixth to first centuries BCE. They formed clustered polities with fortified oppida, controlled valleys and trade routes, and adopted coinage, ironworking, and refined ceramics through contact with Greeks at Emporion and Phoenician-Carthaginian ports. Iberian scripts (northeastern and southeastern) appear on stone, pottery, and coin. Artistic production includes stone sculptures such as the Lady of Elche and the Bicha de Balazote.
Iberian groups fielded skilled cavalry and served as mercenaries in the Punic and Roman armies. The Second Punic War began with the siege of Saguntum, and Roman conquest proceeded region by region. By the first century BCE, Iberian polities were absorbed into Roman Hispania as municipia and colonies. Their urban layouts, agricultural practices, and epigraphic habits shaped the Roman provincial order that followed, while Turdetanian law and literacy persisted in Baetica.

types.name: Iceni
types.description:
The Iceni were a Late Iron Age people of eastern Britain, centered in modern Norfolk and north Suffolk. Before Rome they minted distinctive gold and silver coins and produced fine torcs, seen in the Snettisham hoards. Their society was led by regional elites and linked to Belgic and North Sea trade.

After the Roman invasion of 43 CE, the Iceni became a client kingdom under Prasutagus. On his death, Roman seizures and abuses triggered the revolt led by Boudica in 60–61. The uprising destroyed Colchester, London, and St Albans before defeat by Suetonius Paulinus. Rome then reorganized the region as the civitas of the Iceni, with its center at Venta Icenorum near Caistor St Edmund. Over the next centuries, rural estates, pottery industries, and roads integrated the area into Roman Britain’s economy and administration.

types.name: Inca
types.description: The Inca formed the imperial state of Tawantinsuyu in the thirteenth to sixteenth centuries, with Cusco as capital. Expansion under Pachacuti, Topa Inca Yupanqui, and Huayna Capac created a multiethnic empire linked by the Qhapaq Ñan road system, bridges, and way stations. Administration used a decimal hierarchy, mit'a labor drafts, storehouses, and quipus for information management. Agricultural terraces, qollqa granaries, and irrigation secured surpluses across vertical ecological zones. State religion centered on the Sun cult and veneration of royal mummies. Stone architecture at Sacsayhuamán, Ollantaytambo, and Machu Picchu displayed precise joinery and planned urban layouts. Resettlement (mitmaqkuna), alliances, and garrisons maintained order. A civil war between Huáscar and Atahualpa weakened the realm before the Spanish invasion of 1532. Pizarro captured and executed Atahualpa, took Cusco, and ended independent rule by 1533, though resistance at Vilcabamba lasted to 1572. Inca language, community organization, and agricultural systems endured within colonial and republican Peru.

types.name: India
types.description:
Modern India emerged from late colonial rule and the nationalist movement. The Indian National Congress (1885) organized constitutional agitation, then mass politics under M. K. Gandhi. Independence and Partition came in 1947. The Republic adopted a democratic constitution in 1950, with universal franchise, fundamental rights, and federal reorganization along linguistic lines. Early policy mixed planning with land reform and state-led industrialization; the Green Revolution raised grain output. India tested nuclear devices in 1974 and 1998.

Economic liberalization in 1991 opened markets, accelerated growth, and expanded services, especially information technology. ISRO developed launch vehicles and planetary missions, including Mars Orbiter (2014) and Chandrayaan‑3 (2023). India pursues nonalignment-derived strategic autonomy, maintains a large military, and engages in regional and global forums, including a G20 presidency in 2023. Persistent challenges include inequality, infrastructure gaps, environmental stress, and communal tensions. The country remains a populous federal democracy with a diversified economy and growing scientific and industrial capacity.

types.name: Indonesia
types.description:
Indonesia emerged from early modern colonial structures built by the Dutch East India Company after 1602. Batavia became a hub for spice monopolies, forced contracts, and inter‑island shipping. After the VOC’s dissolution in 1799, the Dutch state consolidated the Netherlands Indies. The Cultivation System (1830–1870) financed the metropole but provoked resistance. The Ethical Policy expanded education and infrastructure. Railways, telegraphs, and plantations tied islands into an integrated economy.

National awakening accelerated from 1908 with Budi Utomo, Sarekat Islam, and the Youth Pledge of 1928 adopting Bahasa Indonesia. Japanese occupation (1942–1945) mobilized resources and militias. Sukarno and Hatta proclaimed independence on 17 August 1945. The revolution ended with Dutch recognition in 1949. The republic moved from parliamentary rule to Sukarno’s Guided Democracy, then to Suharto’s New Order after 1965, which combined centralized authority with rapid growth and ASEAN leadership. Since 1998, democratic reforms, decentralization, and steady expansion have defined politics. Indonesia is a G20 member with regional influence, diverse industries, and ongoing challenges in inequality, governance, and the environment. Capital relocation to Nusantara is underway.

types.name: Iran
types.description:
The modern Iranian state formed after the Safavid collapse through Afsharid and Zand interludes and the Qajar dynasty (1796–1925). Qajar Iran navigated Anglo-Russian rivalry, granted concessions, and saw the Tobacco Protest (1891–92) and the Constitutional Revolution (1905–11), which created a parliament and basic law. Reza Shah Pahlavi (1925–41) centralized authority, built railways, standardized law, and expanded education. Mohammad Reza Shah pursued oil-backed industrialization; the 1951 nationalization under Mossadegh and the 1953 coup reshaped politics. The White Revolution accelerated social change. The 1979 Islamic Revolution ended the monarchy and established the Islamic Republic.

The Iran–Iraq War (1980–88) devastated the economy but entrenched state institutions. Postwar governments rebuilt industry, expanded petrochemicals, and developed missiles, drones, and a nuclear program. Sanctions and fluctuating oil prices constrained growth and spurred import substitution. The 2015 JCPOA briefly eased tensions; a U.S. withdrawal in 2018 renewed sanctions. Iran projects regional influence through allied groups and maintains active diplomacy. Society is urbanized and educated, with major cinema, literature, and tech sectors and a global diaspora. Elections and civil activism coexist with clerical oversight and internal security control. Protests in 2009 and 2022–23 signaled ongoing debates over governance and social policy.

types.name: Iraq
types.description:
The modern state of Iraq formed from the former Ottoman vilayets after the 1920 British occupation and League of Nations Mandate. The Hashemite Kingdom gained formal independence in 1932. Coups and army politics culminated in the 1958 revolution and a republican order. The Ba’athists took power in 1968; Saddam Hussein ruled from 1979, centralizing security institutions and the oil economy. The Iran–Iraq War devastated industry and finances. The 1990 Kuwait invasion triggered the 1991 Gulf War and sanctions. State capacity eroded while education and health declined.

In 2003 a US-led coalition overthrew the regime. A new constitution in 2005 created a federal parliamentary system and recognized the Kurdistan Region. Insurgency and sectarian conflict peaked in 2006–2007. The Islamic State captured Mosul in 2014; Iraqi forces and allies retook major cities by 2017. Iraq remains a major OPEC producer with recurring protests over services, corruption, and jobs. Politics revolve around coalition governments, militia influence, and federal–regional bargaining. Recovery focuses on rebuilding, diversifying beyond oil, and adapting to water scarcity and climate stress across the Tigris–Euphrates basin.

types.name: Iroquois
types.description:
The Haudenosaunee (Iroquois) Confederacy formed in the late precontact era, uniting the Mohawk, Oneida, Onondaga, Cayuga, and Seneca under the Great Law of Peace; the Tuscarora joined in the early 18th century. Longhouse villages, fortified towns, and maize–bean–squash agriculture anchored a dense population in what is now New York and southern Ontario. In the 17th century they fought the Beaver Wars against Algonquin- and Wendat-allied groups, then balanced Dutch, French, and English interests through diplomacy such as the Covenant Chain.
The American Revolution split councils; British-aligned nations migrated to Upper Canada and settled along the Grand River and Bay of Quinte. The 19th–20th centuries brought land cessions, pressures on traditional governance, and missionary schools, yet confederacy institutions persisted. In the late 20th century, land-rights actions by Mohawk and other nations asserted treaty and title claims. Today Haudenosaunee communities straddle the US–Canada border, maintain councils, and engage in cross-border trade, cultural renewal, and legal negotiations.

types.name: Italy
types.description:
The Kingdom of Italy formed in 1861 under the House of Savoy and incorporated Rome in 1870. Unification created a centralized state but left regional disparities. Industrialization accelerated in the North, while the South faced land and labor shortages. Mass emigration reshaped society. Italy fought in World War I on the Entente side. Fascism seized power in 1922, pursued corporatism and imperial war, and fell after military defeat in World War II. A referendum in 1946 established the republic; the 1948 constitution created a parliamentary system.

The postwar economic boom transformed Italy into a major manufacturer with global strength in machinery, automobiles, fashion, and design. Italy was a founding member of NATO and the European Communities. The 1970s saw social conflict and terrorism; the 1990s corruption probes reconfigured parties. Italy adopted the euro, expanded high-speed rail, and invested in heritage conservation. Challenges include public debt, demographic decline, North–South inequality, and climate adaptation. Italy remains a G7 economy and EU anchor, active in Mediterranean policy, cultural industries, advanced manufacturing, and renewable technologies into the 2020s.

types.name: Japan
types.description: From the Meiji Restoration in 1868, Japan pursued rapid modernization. Domains were abolished, conscription and national schooling introduced, and railways, telegraph, and factories built. The state fostered heavy industry through zaibatsu. Victory in the Sino-Japanese War and Russo-Japanese War expanded influence; Korea was annexed in 1910. Interwar years saw party cabinets and social unrest, then military ascendancy. War in China from 1937 and the Pacific War ended in 1945 with defeat and atomic bombings. The U.S. occupation enacted land reform, civil liberties, and the 1947 constitution. Postwar growth from the 1950s to 1980s made Japan a leader in autos, electronics, and shipbuilding. The 1990s asset bubble collapse brought stagnation. Since 2000, policy has sought revitalization while addressing aging and low fertility. Japan remains a major economy, a technology and cultural exporter, and a key U.S. ally. Recent decades include the 2011 earthquake and Fukushima crisis, defense reform debates, and expanded regional security partnerships.

types.name: Jōmon
types.description: The Jōmon period spans roughly 14,000–300 BCE. Communities lived in pit dwellings and practiced a broad-spectrum economy of fishing, shellfish gathering, hunting, and nut processing. They produced some of the world’s earliest pottery, marked with cord impressions, and developed lacquerwork. Shell middens, obsidian quarries, and jade ornaments show regional exchange networks. Ritual is visible in dogū figurines and stone circles. Later phases adopted small-scale cultivation of millet and buckwheat, with possible dry-field rice in the south. Forest management and seasonal mobility supported relatively dense coastal settlements. Distinct regional styles formed in Tōhoku, Kantō, Chūbu, and Kyūshū. By the first millennium BCE contacts with the continent increased. New populations and techniques entered via Korea. These changes prepared the ground for irrigated rice agriculture, bronze and iron tools, and deeper social stratification. The transition defines the move into the Yayoi horizon.

types.name: Kandy
types.description: The Kandyan Kingdom formed in the central highlands by the late 15th century. Its mountain terrain, mobile warfare, and alliance diplomacy enabled it to resist Portuguese and later Dutch coastal powers. Under Vimaladharmasuriya I and Rajasinha II, the court defended independence, negotiated the 1638 treaty with the Dutch, and managed shifting vassal networks. Administration rested on local chiefs (dissavas) and service tenures. The Temple of the Tooth in Kandy anchored royal authority. A monastic revival drew higher ordination from Siam in 1753 under Kirti Sri Rajasinha, reshaping Buddhist learning and art in a distinct Kandyan style. Internal elite rivalries and British expansion eroded autonomy. In 1815 nobles deposed Sri Vikrama Rajasinha and ceded the kingdom by the Kandyan Convention. Uprisings in 1818 and 1848 followed.
