The Spanish discovery of Potosí and Andean lodes in the sixteenth century produced unprecedented output. Silver pesos, the “piece of eight,” became a global medium of exchange. Manila galleons moved American silver to Asia, where Chinese tax demands in silver drove sustained flows. The European Price Revolution reflected bullion influx and monetary expansion. Mints shifted standards between bimetallism and gold ratios in the nineteenth century. Silversmithing framed social display from Islamic courts to European guilds. Photography, electrical contacts, and medical alloys added modern uses, though coinage declined with fiat currency.

types.name: Soy Beans
types.description: Soya bean (Glycine max) agriculture began in northern China by the late Neolithic. Farmers valued the plant for seed protein and for nitrogen fixation in rotations with millet, wheat, and rice. Han and later dynasties documented tofu, soy milk, and fermented pastes. Techniques diverged regionally into Chinese jiang, Japanese miso and shoyu, and Korean doenjang and ganjang. By the seventeenth century the crop spread to Japan and Korea at scale. Western awareness grew after eighteenth-century botanic exchanges. Industrial crushing in the twentieth century made soybean oil and meal central to global food and feed. The crop moved into Brazil and the United States Midwest through breeding for temperate day lengths. Soya remains a cornerstone of East Asian cuisines and world protein supply.

types.name: Squid
types.description: Squid have long served as food, bait, and regional trade goods. Mediterranean and East Asian cuisines featured fresh, dried, and fried preparations documented since antiquity. Jigging and purse seine techniques expanded catches in the twentieth century, targeting species such as Loligo, Illex, and Dosidicus. Dried and salted squid circulated through coastal markets in Japan, Korea, and Southeast Asia. Fisheries also supplied bait for tunas and other pelagic species in longline fleets. Industrial-scale operations emerged in the South Atlantic and North Pacific with night-lighting and specialized gear. Markets diversified as calamari entered global restaurant menus. Management focuses on short-lived stock dynamics, seasonal closures, and bycatch control. Historical records from ports and market books trace shifting centers of production and trade corridors.

types.name: Steel
types.description: Steel is an iron-carbon alloy that became central to industrial society. Early steels appeared in antiquity, including crucible and pattern-welded varieties. Modern mass production began in the 19th century with the Bessemer converter and open-hearth process, followed by basic oxygen and electric-arc methods. Steel enabled railway rails, steamship hulls, and the expansion of heavy industry. Engineers adopted steel frameworks for bridges and skyscrapers, transforming urban skylines. Machine tools and factory equipment relied on its strength and toughness. During World Wars I and II, steel underpinned armaments, armor, and logistics. Standardized grades and heat treatment allowed predictable performance in harsh conditions. By the mid-20th century, global steelmaking supported automobiles, household appliances, pipelines, and large-scale infrastructure.

types.name: Steel Alloy
types.description: Steel alloys add elements such as chromium, nickel, molybdenum, tungsten, and vanadium to tailor performance. Alloying with chromium and nickel produces stainless steel with corrosion resistance for cutlery, medical devices, and chemical plants. Tool steels with tungsten or molybdenum hold hard cutting edges and tolerate heat, supporting machining and dies. High-tensile grades serve automobiles, aircraft, and pressure vessels. Chromium-vanadium steels power springs and high-stress components. Controlled heat treatment and tempering further adjust strength and toughness. Development accelerated in the early 20th century with standardized compositions and tests. Alloy steels enabled lighter structures, longer service life, and safer operation across transport, energy, and manufacturing sectors.

types.name: Sugar
types.description: Sugar is a crystalline sweetener produced mainly from sugarcane and, since the 19th century, sugar beet. Cane cultivation spread from South and Southeast Asia through the Islamic world to the Mediterranean. From the 16th century, the Atlantic plantation complex in Brazil and the Caribbean industrialized sugar making, with mills, boiling houses, and transoceanic shipping. Molasses and rum became integral to Atlantic trade. European demand drove expansion of plantations and the forced labor of enslaved Africans. Technological advances, including vacuum pans and centrifuges, increased yields in the 19th century. Beet sugar developed in Europe during the Napoleonic era and grew after abolition, diversifying supply. By the 20th century, sugar was a mass commodity underpinning confectionery, beverages, and processed foods.

types.name: Tamarind
types.description: Tamarind is a tropical African tree producing tart-sweet pods used for cooking, medicine, and craft. It spread early to South Asia, where it became integral to Indian cuisines, chutneys, and curries. Ayurvedic texts record digestive and cooling uses. Historical sources attest to its role as a souring agent in Ethiopian and Egyptian preparations. Across the Indian Ocean, Arab and Portuguese trade dispersed tamarind to Southeast Asia, where it entered regional sauces, candies, and beverages. The fruit pulp aided preservation, while seeds and kernels served as thickeners. Wood and tannins supported carpentry, tanning, and metal polishing. In the 19th century, tamarind entered European condiments, including Worcestershire sauce. Its durable pods and broad utility anchored it in household, market, and maritime networks.

types.name: Taro
types.description: Taro is a starchy aroid cultivated for corms and leaves in tropical and subtropical zones. Likely domesticated in Island Southeast Asia and New Guinea, it traveled with Austronesian voyagers across the Pacific. In Polynesia and Melanesia it formed a primary staple, organized in irrigated patches and dry gardens. Hawaiians developed loi systems that integrated water flow, fish, and soil renewal. Cooked and pounded taro produced poi for daily meals and ceremonies. Corms stored well for feasts and voyages. Taro also entered South and Southeast Asian cuisines as stews and fritters. Its cultural status shaped land tenure and ritual in many islands, while resilience and clonal propagation supported settlement of remote archipelagos.

types.name: Tea
types.description: Tea is a beverage prepared from processed leaves of Camellia sinensis, boiled or infused in water. Originating in China, it entered elite and ritual contexts by the Tang and Song periods, with tribute systems and refined preparation methods. From the 17th century, the Dutch and British East India Companies carried tea to Europe, where demand expanded rapidly. The silver outflow to China and British efforts to balance trade shaped imperial policy, culminating in the Boston Tea Party (1773) and later the Opium Wars. In the 19th century, colonial plantations in Assam, Darjeeling, Ceylon, and Java reorganized supply under European management. By the 20th century, black, green, and oolong teas formed global markets, supported by auction systems and branded blends.

types.name: Tilapia
types.description: Tilapia denotes several cichlid species native to Africa and the Nile basin. Ancient Egyptian tomb art shows tilapia in nets and basins, reflecting early management and consumption. Riverine and lacustrine communities across Africa relied on the fish for everyday protein, using baskets, traps, and shoreline seines. In the mid‑20th century, governments and development agencies promoted pond culture of Nile tilapia to raise rural food supplies. The species adapted to simple earthen ponds and integrated farming, spreading across Asia and Latin America. Trade developed in fresh, iced, and frozen fillets for domestic and export markets. Tilapia remains central to smallholder aquaculture and urban markets, linking ancient capture fisheries with modern farmed production.

types.name: Tin
types.description: Tin is a scarce metal essential for making bronze. Small additions harden copper and improve casting. During the Bronze Age, demand drove long-distance exchange. Probable sources included Cornwall and Devon, Iberia, Brittany, the Erzgebirge, and Central Asia. Trade linked Atlantic Europe with the Mediterranean and Near East. The Uluburun shipwreck shows standardized copper and tin ingots in near-ideal ratios. Control of supply affected elite power, craft production, and warfare. After the Bronze Age, tin continued in pewter alloys, solders, and tinplate. Medieval and early modern mining in Cornwall fed European markets. The rarity of rich ores and the difficulty of tracing provenance make tin networks a key case in archaeometallurgy and ancient economic history.

types.name: Tobacco
types.description: Tobacco is a New World plant cultivated for nicotine-rich leaves processed into smokeable or chewable forms. Indigenous peoples of the Americas used it ritually and medicinally long before European contact. From the 16th century, Spanish and Portuguese traders carried it to Europe and Africa, where demand grew rapidly. In the English colonies, especially Virginia and Maryland, tobacco became a foundational cash crop by the early 17th century, shaping land use, plantation systems, and transatlantic trade. Caribbean islands, notably Cuba and later Jamaica, developed major curing and cigar industries. European states taxed tobacco heavily and often regulated it through monopolies. By the 18th century, snuff, cigars, and pipe tobacco formed a global commodity chain linking American plantations, European markets, and imperial revenues.

types.name: Tuna
types.description: Tuna refers to migratory Thunnus and related genera long pursued in the Mediterranean and adjacent Atlantic. Phoenician and Greek communities used fixed traps and light craft to intercept coastal runs. Roman processors salted loins and rendered sauces that moved widely by amphora. Medieval and early modern tonnare and almadrabas in Sicily, Sardinia, and Andalusia anchored seasonal economies, with lords and towns leasing trap rights. Steam canning and longlines in the 19th–20th centuries expanded reach into oceanic grounds. Conservation regimes later addressed declines in bluefin stocks. Tuna fishing linked coastal labor, preservation industries, and regional commerce for over two millennia.

types.name: Tungsten
types.description: Tungsten is a dense, refractory metal noted for high hardness and the highest melting point among metals. Ores include wolframite and scheelite. Industrial uses developed with tungsten filaments in early incandescent bulbs, then expanded with tungsten carbide tooling for machining and mining. In both world wars, tungsten became a strategic material for armor-piercing cores and anti-armor ordnance. Its density and strength improved penetrators and gun barrels. Control of supply was a wartime objective, involving deposits in China, Portugal, Spain, and Southeast Asia. Postwar, tungsten carbide remained central to high-speed cutting and wear-resistant applications. The metal’s role in precision tooling linked it to modern manufacturing capacity, while military demand persisted for kinetic energy penetrators and high-temperature alloys in aerospace.

types.name: Turnip
types.description: Turnip (Brassica rapa subsp. rapa) is a cool-season root long cultivated in Europe and the Mediterranean. Classical authors described its culture and fodder value. In medieval and early modern Europe it served as a common boiled or mashed vegetable and as winter livestock feed. The eighteenth-century Norfolk four-course rotation used turnips to restore soil fertility and support overwintering animals, enabling higher grain yields and manure supply. Pickling and storage in clamps extended availability through winter. Turnips fed both armies and urban poor during shortages, and retained importance in northern kitchens even after the rise of the potato. Distinct from the later rutabaga, the turnip remained a flexible crop for mixed farming systems across Britain, France, and Scandinavia.

types.name: Turquoise
types.description: Turquoise is a blue to green copper-aluminum phosphate valued for its opaque color and fine polish. Ancient Egyptian mines in Sinai and Persian deposits near Nishapur supplied early jewels and inlays. The material circulated through Anatolian and Mediterranean trade into medieval Europe, giving the stone its French name. In Iran and Central Asia, craftsmen set turquoise in weapon hilts, mosque fittings, and court jewelry. Pre-Columbian Mesoamerica produced mosaics and ceremonial objects for Aztec and Mixtec elites. In the American Southwest, Puebloan, Navajo, and Zuni artisans integrated turquoise with silverwork and ceremonial regalia. Qing workshops combined turquoise with jade and gold for court ornaments. Stabilization and reconstitution techniques expanded modern use as high-grade sources declined.

types.name: Uranium
types.description: Uranium is a heavy, radioactive element central to nuclear energy and nuclear weapons. Natural uranium contains U-235 and U-238; enrichment concentrates U-235 for reactor fuel or weapons. The Manhattan Project (1942–45) built the first atomic weapons, drawing ore from sources such as Shinkolobwe in the Belgian Congo. From the 1950s, commercial reactors produced electricity while military programs sustained mining, enrichment, and reprocessing. During the Cold War, gaseous diffusion and later centrifuge plants became strategic facilities. Uranium deposits in North America, Africa, Central Asia, and Australia fed global supply. Accidents and proliferation concerns shaped policy, leading to safeguards and international oversight. Despite shifts in energy markets, uranium remained a critical resource linking geology, state power, and advanced industrial systems.

types.name: Water Buffalo
types.description: Water buffalo were domesticated in South and Southeast Asia and adapted to wet, heavy soils. As draught animals they powered paddy ploughing and transported loads in flooded landscapes. Their wallowing behavior aided thermoregulation in tropical climates. River and swamp types supported different agro-ecologies. Milk entered regional diets as ghee and yogurt; in the Mediterranean, introduced buffalo supplied mozzarella production. Hides fed local leather trades. In irrigated rice regions, buffalo labor shaped settlement patterns, tenancy, and seasonal work rhythms. Colonial agronomic surveys recorded their distribution and productivity. Mechanization reduced roles in some areas, yet buffalo remain important where fuel and capital are scarce. Iconography, village contracts, and agricultural manuals attest to their long integration with wet-rice systems.

types.name: Whales
types.description: Whales have been exploited for oil, meat, and baleen across many oceans. Basque fleets pioneered organized Atlantic whaling by the Middle Ages. Dutch, British, and American crews expanded the hunt in the early modern era. Nineteenth-century Yankee whalers pursued sperm whales for spermaceti used in high-quality candles and lubricants. Baleen supplied stays for corsets and frames for umbrellas. Indigenous Arctic communities maintained subsistence hunts with deep ritual and social significance. Twentieth-century factory ships and explosive harpoons drove many populations to collapse. The International Whaling Commission formed in 1946 to regulate catches. A global moratorium on commercial whaling began in 1986, with limited exemptions for aboriginal subsistence and scientific quotas. Conservation programs and sanctuaries emerged, while historical whaling ports preserved maritime heritage.

types.name: Wheat
types.description: Wheat is among the earliest domesticated cereals from the Fertile Crescent, with emmer and einkorn cultivated by 9000-8000 BCE. Selection produced free-threshing bread wheat, expanding acreage from the Levant to the Nile and Aegean. Irrigation, plows, and sickles increased surplus, feeding cities and temples in Mesopotamia and dynastic Egypt. Bread and beer formed ration systems for workers and soldiers. As empires expanded, wheat moved along Mediterranean and Silk Road routes, becoming central to Roman annona distributions and later Islamic agronomy. Medieval open fields, three-course rotations, and mills stabilized production. Early modern globalization spread wheat to the Americas and Australia. Industrial milling and rail transport created mass urban bread markets, cementing wheat as a global staple grain.

types.name: Yak
types.description: The yak supported high-altitude societies of the Tibetan Plateau and Himalaya. Domesticated millennia ago, it supplied pack and draught power on passes and fields unsuited to other bovines. Milk, butter, and meat anchored diets where barley dominated cultivation. Hair and wool became ropes, tents, and coarse textiles; hides served as durable covers. Crossbreeds with cattle, known as dzo or dzomo, increased traction and milk yields at lower elevations. Caravans of salt, tea, and wool relied on yak transport across trans-Himalayan routes. Monastic estates and village commons regulated pastures and breeding. Travelogues and trade records from the seventeenth to nineteenth centuries describe seasonal migrations and fairs. The animal remains central to highland economies despite modern roads and mechanized transport.

types.name: Yerba Mate
types.description: Yerba mate is a caffeinated holly native to subtropical South America, brewed from dried leaves and shared communally with a gourd and metal straw. The Guaraní cultivated and consumed it long before Spanish colonization. In the 17th and 18th centuries, Jesuit missions organized plantations and trade networks along the Paraná and Paraguay rivers, securing a regional monopoly. After the expulsion of the Jesuits, production expanded under colonial and later national authorities in Paraguay, Argentina, and Brazil. By the 19th century, mate was entrenched as a daily beverage in the Río de la Plata and southern Brazil, with commercial centers in Misiones and Rio Grande do Sul. It remains a defining commodity and social drink in Paraguay, Argentina, Uruguay, and southern Brazil.

types.name: Canal
types.description: Canals are artificial waterways cut to move bulk cargo and passengers where rivers do not run or are unreliable. They flourished during the industrial era when mines and mills demanded cheap transport. Engineers used locks, pound levels, towpaths, and aqueducts to manage gradients and crossings. The Bridgewater Canal of 1761 linked coal pits to Manchester and triggered a British canal boom. The Erie Canal opened in 1825, connecting the Great Lakes to the Hudson and slashing freight costs to New York. The Suez Canal of 1869 created a sea passage between the Mediterranean and Red Sea and reshaped global routes. Financing came from investors and states. Railroads reduced many inland canals, yet strategic ship canals and modern barge networks remain vital.

types.name: Cobbled Road
types.description: Cobbled roads are stone-paved surfaces designed to carry carts, riders, and foot traffic with improved durability. In the classical world they supported military movement, trade, and urban sanitation. Roman engineers laid polygonal basalt or limestone on compacted rubble with a cambered surface for drainage. Curbstones, side ditches, and milestones aided maintenance and navigation. The Appian Way, begun in 312 BCE, linked Rome to Capua and southern Italy. The Via Egnatia crossed the Balkans and tied Adriatic ports to Byzantium. Stone streets at Pompeii preserve wheel ruts and stepping stones. Similar paving later appeared in medieval towns and early modern capitals. Cobbles reduced rutting and winter mud, though they produced vibration and noise. Their legacy survives in historic centers and preserved road segments.

types.name: Dirt Road
types.description: Dirt roads are unpaved tracks formed by repeated travel and simple grading. They emerged in the Bronze Age alongside the earliest wheels and draft animals. Surfaces used compacted earth with occasional gravel, brush, or straw for reinforcement. Drainage depended on ruts, shallow ditches, and a crowned profile. Width matched ox carts and wagons. Sumerian trade routes between Uruk and nearby cities carried textiles, grain, and stone. Indus Valley ox-cart paths linked towns and fields. Minoan wagon tracks on Crete cut through limestone and soil. Such routes enabled migration, seasonal herding, and regional markets. They were cheap to extend but vulnerable to mud, dust, and erosion. Many medieval and early modern roads retained dirt surfaces. Numerous modern highways follow these ancient alignments.

types.name: Motorway
types.description: Motorways are controlled-access divided highways designed for sustained high-speed motor travel. They use grade separation, medians, limited entrances, and safety barriers to maintain flow and reduce conflicts. Pavements follow strict design speeds, lane widths, and sight distances. Service areas and intelligent traffic systems support operations. Large programs expanded networks in the early twenty-first century. China extended the National Trunk Highway System, including the G30 corridor across the northwest. India completed the Golden Quadrilateral in 2012, linking Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai, and Kolkata. The European Union advanced TEN-T motorway upgrades to integrate member states and freight routes. Motorways foster regional integration and just-in-time logistics. They also raise issues of congestion, emissions, land acquisition, and toll finance.

types.name: Railroad
types.description: Railroads are steel-track systems that guide flanged-wheel vehicles for efficient land transport. Standardized gauge, ballasted sleepers, and switchwork form the permanent way. Traffic runs by timetables, signaling, and centralized control. Steam dominated in the nineteenth century, then diesel and electric traction advanced performance. By 1916 the Trans-Siberian Railway created a continuous link across Eurasia and reshaped imperial logistics. From 1964 the Tokaido Shinkansen demonstrated reliable high-speed passenger service. European mainline electrification programs improved acceleration, capacity, and energy efficiency. Railways carried ore, grain, mail, and troops at scale. They concentrated industry and enabled commuting. Containerization after mid century integrated rail with ports and highways. Despite competition from road and air, rail remains a backbone of dense corridors.

types.name: Bonus Yield Surge
types.description: Double Yield for 5 turns.

types.name: Bonus Yield Turn
types.description: Double Yield for 1 turn.

types.name: Exceptional Output
types.description: A requirement of exceptional output over time.

types.name: Extra Output
types.description: A requirement of extra output over time.

types.name: Extra Resources
types.description: A requirement of acquiring extra resources over time.

types.name: Increase Resource Yield
types.description: 1 extra resource per turn.

types.name: Atom Bomb
types.description: An atom bomb is a fission weapon that releases energy by rapidly splitting heavy nuclei, producing blast, heat, and ionizing radiation. The United States built the first devices during the Manhattan Project, culminating in the Trinity test in July 1945. Days later, atomic bombs destroyed Hiroshima and Nagasaki, prompting Japan’s surrender and ending the Second World War in the Pacific. Early designs used gun-type and implosion assemblies with uranium-235 or plutonium-239. Postwar programs in the Soviet Union, United Kingdom, France, and China expanded nuclear arsenals and delivery systems. The technology reshaped strategy through deterrence doctrines and civil defense planning. Arms control efforts, including the Partial Test Ban Treaty and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, sought to limit testing, spread, and deployment while maintaining safeguards and verification.

types.name: Disease Projectile
types.description: Disease projectiles were medieval siege munitions that used corpses, offal, or contaminated materials to degrade defenders’ health and morale. Sources describe besiegers loading trebuchets with carcasses or waste and hurling them over walls. The best known episode occurred at Caffa in 1346, when attacking forces reportedly threw plague-infected bodies into the Genoese-held city during the Black Death. Earlier and later sieges also employed animal carcasses to foul water and spread putrefaction. The tactic relied on fear and unsanitary conditions rather than controlled epidemiology, and its direct role in transmitting specific diseases remains debated. With the rise of early modern military hygiene and emerging international norms, such practices declined. Twentieth-century treaties, including the 1925 Geneva Protocol and later the Biological Weapons Convention, codified prohibitions on biological methods of warfare.

types.name: Gas Projectile
types.description: Gas projectiles are artillery shells or mortars designed to disseminate toxic chemical agents on detonation. During the First World War, after initial cloud releases, belligerents adopted shells to deliver chlorine, phosgene, and mustard agents with greater precision and persistence. Major offensives from 1915 to 1918 saw extensive shelling with gas munitions on the Western and Eastern Fronts, prompting rapid development of masks, filters, and protective drills. Shell-based delivery enabled mixed barrages that combined high explosive and chemical effects against trenches and artillery positions. Postwar condemnation shaped the 1925 Geneva Protocol, which banned chemical warfare. States nevertheless retained stockpiles for decades, though battlefield use dwindled under legal and strategic constraints. By the late twentieth century, international regimes sought verified destruction of chemical munitions under the Chemical Weapons Convention.

types.name: Hydrogen Bomb
types.description: A hydrogen bomb is a thermonuclear weapon that uses a fission primary to drive fusion in a secondary stage, yielding far greater energy than pure fission devices. The United States tested the first thermonuclear design in 1952, followed by the Soviet Union in 1953. Subsequent advances produced lighter, deliverable warheads and very high-yield tests, such as the Soviet Tsar Bomba in 1961. In the twenty-first century, several nuclear states have maintained and modernized thermonuclear arsenals, focusing on safety, reliability, and miniaturization for varied delivery systems. North Korea announced thermonuclear tests in 2016 and 2017, intensifying proliferation concerns and sanctions. Contemporary policy centers on deterrence postures, test moratoria, and stockpile stewardship programs, alongside efforts to prevent further spread under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

types.name: Planet Buster
types.description: A planet buster is a hypothetical doomsday device capable of inflicting planet-scale devastation through staged thermonuclear fusion with multi-gigaton yields. The idea belongs to science fiction and speculative military thought rather than practicable engineering. Writers and designers have posited chained fusion stages, antimatter triggers, or asteroid-delivery hybrids to bridge the gap between known weapons and extinction-level effects. No technology approaches such performance; even the largest historical test, the 1961 Tsar Bomba, remained many orders of magnitude below global destruction. Discussions often compare required energies to major impact events, such as the Chicxulub asteroid. The concept serves as a narrative tool for exploring ethics, deterrence, and catastrophe in literature, film, and games, while underscoring the limits and dangers of nuclear escalation.

types.name: Virus Bomb
types.description: Virus bombs are a speculative class of warheads designed to disperse engineered viruses as aerosols over wide areas. The concept appears in late twentieth- and twenty-first-century fiction and policy debates about emerging biotechnology. Proposed mechanisms envision tailored pathogens, genetic payloads, or delivery systems optimized for environmental stability and transmission, often invoking CRISPR-era modification. No state has acknowledged such weapons, and practical barriers remain high, including agent survivability, control of spread, and unpredictable epidemiology. International law prohibits development and possession under the Biological Weapons Convention, reinforced by biosafety standards and export controls. Public discourse treats the idea as a cautionary scenario about dual-use research and biodefense. Notable cultural treatments include novels and games that examine strategic and ethical consequences rather than technical feasibility.

types.name: Aerodynamics
types.description: Aerodynamics examines airflow and the forces it produces on moving bodies. Early aviation coupled wind-tunnel testing with theory to establish lift, drag, and stability criteria. Ludwig Prandtl’s boundary-layer concept and NACA’s systematic airfoil series gave designers reliable performance data. Compressibility effects at high speed prompted study of shock waves, critical Mach number, and transonic behavior. Supersonic wind tunnels and schlieren imaging enabled research on cones, wedges, and area ruling. The jet age demanded refined inlet, nozzle, and wing designs, while missiles required slender bodies and control in rarified regimes. Postwar advances merged experiments with numerical methods, and later computational fluid dynamics, guiding aircraft, rotorcraft, and reentry vehicles. The field remains central to fuel efficiency, noise control, and high-speed flight.

quote.text: Sleek lines win the race before it starts.

types.name: Agriculture
types.description: Agriculture began as the cultivation of cereals and pulses in the early Holocene. In the Fertile Crescent, wheat and barley were domesticated alongside lentils and peas. Settled villages stored harvests in silos and processed grain with sickles and grinding stones. Along the Yangtze, early paddy systems fostered rice domestication and wet-field management. Irrigation on the Tigris and Euphrates stabilized yields and allowed expansion onto alluvial plains. The ard plow and simple field systems increased labor efficiency and supported larger households. Surplus production promoted craft specialization, taxation, and the rise of hierarchical institutions. Seasonal calendars, land tenure, and ritual cycles integrated cultivation with social life. Over time, mixed farming combined crops with livestock for manure and traction. Agriculture transformed landscapes through deforestation, terraces, and canals. It generated enduring exchange networks for seed, tools, and knowledge that linked villages and early cities across Southwest Asia, the Nile Valley, South Asia, and East Asia.

quote.text: Bread is the reward of honest toil.

types.name: Alphabet
types.description: Classical alphabets encoded speech through a fixed set of letters, enabling flexible writing and rapid learning. Greeks adapted the Phoenician script and introduced vowel letters, improving phonetic accuracy across dialects. Early inscriptions, such as the Duenos inscription in Latin, display local variants that later converged. The Greek and Latin alphabets spread with colonization, trade, and administration, appearing on stone, pottery, papyrus, and metal. Alphabetic writing supported law codes, drama, philosophy, and commerce by reducing copying costs and aiding record‑keeping. Its modular design encouraged literacy across diverse communities and domains.

quote.text: The Phoenicians taught us letters.

types.name: Aluminum Milling
types.description: Aluminum milling is the precision removal of material from aluminum alloys using rotating cutters. The process grew with the widespread availability of aluminum after the Hall–Héroult process and the demands of airframe production. High spindle speeds, sharp rake geometries, and flood coolants enable clean shear and chip evacuation while limiting built-up edge. World War II production standardized fixtures, jigs, and tolerance control for ribs, spars, and skins. Postwar, numerically controlled and later CNC machine tools delivered repeatability and complex contours, including monolithic milled structures that reduce fasteners and weight. Automotive and consumer goods adopted similar methods for lightweight components. Tooling evolved to carbide and coated cutters, while fixturing and probing improved accuracy on thin-walled parts.

quote.text: This is aluminum, aluminum for our industries and aluminum for our homes.

types.name: Animal Husbandry
types.description: Animal husbandry developed with the domestication of goat and sheep in the Zagros and adjacent regions by the early Neolithic. Herd management soon included cattle and pigs in Southwest Asia and neighboring areas. Pastoral practices in Mesopotamia combined sheep flocks for wool with cattle for traction and meat. Selective breeding favored docility, milk yield, and fleece quality. Dairying produced yogurt, cheese, and clarified butter, expanding storage options and nutrition. Herding strategies ranged from village-based pens to transhumant movements between seasonal pastures. Manure fertilized fields and closed nutrient cycles with nearby crops. Secondary products such as wool and leather fed craft industries and long-distance trade. Animal power increased agricultural productivity through plowing and transport. Husbandry also introduced new disease dynamics to human communities. Administrative records, herd counts, and ration lists in early cities attest to the economic centrality of managed livestock throughout the ancient Near East and beyond.

quote.text: Know well your flocks; you will not lack.

types.name: Antibiotics
types.description: Antibiotics are compounds that kill or inhibit bacteria, transforming clinical outcomes for infectious disease. Sulfonamides in the 1930s offered the first widely used synthetic antibacterials. Penicillin, discovered by Alexander Fleming and mass-produced during World War II through deep-tank fermentation, reduced mortality from wound infections and pneumonia. Streptomycin, isolated in 1943, opened effective treatment for tuberculosis and broadened the spectrum against Gram-negative organisms. Postwar discovery programs yielded tetracyclines, macrolides, and cephalosporins, while semisynthetic modifications improved stability and dosing. Widespread use in medicine and agriculture selected for resistance, prompting stewardship, surveillance, and combination therapies. Manufacturing integrated strain selection, bioreactors, and purification, embedding antibiotics into modern public health and surgical practice.

quote.text: The miracle in the mold.

types.name: Archery
types.description: Archery was a foundational military skill across classical Eurasia, serving both infantry and cavalry. Self bows of wood coexisted with powerful composite bows of horn, wood, and sinew crafted by specialist bowyers. The Achaemenid Persians fielded large archer contingents using massed volleys behind shields, while Scythian and other steppe peoples perfected mounted archery with short, reflex bows and hit-and-run tactics. Arrowheads of bronze and later iron were tailored for armor penetration or cutting wounds; quivers, wrist guards, and thumb rings equipped archers for sustained fire. Training emphasized draw strength, rapid shooting, and range estimation. In regions favoring heavy infantry, such as many Greek poleis, archers served as skirmishers and auxiliaries, yet remained decisive in sieges and open battles where mobility and missiles could disrupt dense formations.

quote.text: The bow kills from afar.

types.name: Arches
types.description: Classical arches used wedge-shaped stone voussoirs set over wooden centering and locked by a keystone to redirect vertical loads into lateral thrust carried by piers or abutments. Builders employed stone, brick, and Roman concrete, enabling durable spans in bridges, aqueduct arcades, gates, drains, and vaulted substructures. Repeated arches formed arcades and supported barrel and groin vaults, extending the technique into large interior spaces. Construction required precise stone cutting, mortar bonding, and careful foundation work to resist spreading forces. Roman military engineers and state-sponsored projects standardized arch use across roads and water systems, allowing infrastructure to cross rivers, valleys, and uneven terrain while supporting urban expansion, logistics, and monumentality.

quote.text: Build so it endures.

types.name: Architecture
types.description: Enlightenment architecture integrated Baroque display with rational planning and improved construction science. Urban rebuilding after disasters, as in Wren’s London churches, applied survey control and fireproofing. Court and civic patrons commissioned palaces and theatres with advanced acoustics and circulation. Engineers adapted fortification geometry under Vauban’s influence, refining bastions and glacis. Pattern books and academies spread proportional canons and structural calculation. Late in the period, Neoclassicism drew on antiquity, favoring clear volumes and ordered facades tied to new materials and standardized components.

quote.text: The mason’s hand endures in the stone.

types.name: Art Deco
types.description: Art Deco was a global design movement of the 1920s and 1930s, uniting geometric forms with modern materials and a polished machine-age aesthetic. It drew visibility from the 1925 Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes in Paris. Architecture and interiors employed chrome, lacquer, exotic woods, and glass to convey luxury and speed. The Chrysler Building in New York displayed stylized motifs and stepped massing. Ocean liners such as SS Normandie showcased streamlined ornament and integrated lighting. Graphic arts used bold color blocks, sans-serif type, and stylized figures in posters and packaging. Regional variants emerged in North America, Europe, South Asia, and Latin America. After World War II its influence waned as International Style modernism advanced, later returning through heritage preservation.

quote.text: The city wears its finest dress in steel.

types.name: Art History
types.description: Art history arose in the Enlightenment as a systematic study of artworks, styles, and patrons across time. Johann Joachim Winckelmann’s History of Ancient Art (1764) proposed chronological development and valued classical antiquity, guiding neoclassical taste. Royal academies formalized training, connoisseurship, and critique. Museums and cabinets expanded into public collections with cataloging practices that documented provenance and technique. Travel, archaeology, and antiquarian inquiry widened the corpus to include ancient Mediterranean, medieval, and non‑European material. By the nineteenth century, art history employed comparative analysis, periodization, and stylistic schools to interpret production and reception within cultural contexts.

quote.text: Every age has its own art.

types.name: Artificial Intelligence
types.description: Artificial Intelligence enables machines to perceive, learn, and act. Early symbolic systems and neural networks cycled through optimism and setbacks. The field advanced rapidly after 2010 as large datasets and GPUs unlocked deep learning. ImageNet breakthroughs in 2012 established convolutional networks for vision. AlphaGo’s 2016 victory demonstrated reinforcement learning at scale. Transformer architectures, introduced in 2017, drove major progress in language modeling and multimodal systems. AI now supports translation, recommendation, speech recognition, medical imaging, logistics, and elements of autonomy. Toolchains integrate optimized hardware, distributed training, and MLOps. Research addresses robustness, interpretability, and alignment with human goals. Policy frameworks evolved to manage data governance and safety. The discipline remains a fast‑moving synthesis of algorithms, compute, and real‑world deployment.

quote.text: Success in creating AI would be the biggest event in human history.

types.name: Artillery
types.description: Industrial artillery shifted from cast bronze to steel, from muzzle-loading to breech-loading mechanisms, and from black powder to improved propellants. Precision machining and metallurgy allowed stronger barrels and tighter tolerances. Firms like Krupp supplied field and siege guns that dominated conflicts such as the Franco–Prussian War. Recoil systems at the century’s end, notably on the French 75 mm modèle 1897, permitted rapid aimed fire without re-laying. Indirect fire techniques, panoramic sights, and shrapnel and high-explosive shells expanded tactical roles. Rail and coastal artillery extended range and weight of shot. Artillery became the decisive arm for bombardment, counter-battery, and support.

quote.text: Gentlemen, you have before you the howitzer.

types.name: Atomic Theory
types.description: Modern atomic theory in the early twentieth century located mass and positive charge in a compact nucleus with electrons occupying quantized states. Ernest Rutherford’s gold‑foil experiment (1911) demonstrated nuclear structure; Niels Bohr’s model (1913) applied quantum postulates to hydrogen spectra. Discovery of the neutron (1932) clarified isotopes and mass defects. Quantum mechanics in the 1920s–1930s replaced orbital pictures with wavefunctions and probabilistic interpretation, explaining chemical bonding and periodic behavior. Experimental tools—spectroscopy, scattering, cloud chambers, and later accelerators—validated subatomic particles and transitions. The framework unified physics and chemistry, enabling nuclear energy research, radiochemistry, semiconductor theory, and precise metrology.

quote.text: Atoms are the bricks of the universe.
quote.source: Physics lecture, University of Cambridge, ca. 1923

types.name: Automatic Carbines
types.description: Automatic carbines are compact, shoulder-fired rifles with selective or fully automatic fire. They are optimized for close to medium ranges and mobile troops. The type grew from interwar work on lightweight self-loading arms and matured in World War II. The U.S. M2 Carbine added burst fire for infantry and rear-echelon units in the Korean War. The Soviet AKS-74U condensed assault-rifle firepower for vehicle crews and special forces. It traded barrel length for portability. Later, modular bullpup designs such as the FN F2000 integrated optics, rails, and improved ergonomics. Automatic carbines shaped urban tactics, convoy defense, and airborne operations. They bridged the gap between submachine guns and standard assault rifles.

quote.text: An individual weapon intended to destroy enemy personnel.

types.name: Ballistics
types.description: Ballistics studies projectile behavior in three domains: internal, external, and terminal. Industrial-age artillery produced formal firing tables and new instruments. World War I methods accounted for propellant temperature, barrel wear, wind, and the rotation of the Earth. Rocket and missile programs extended external ballistics to supersonic and exoatmospheric flight. V-2 work drove early trajectory computation. Cold War research modeled reentry for ICBMs, including ablation, plasma effects, and accuracy. Modern ballistics supports forensic analysis, guided weapons, and computational fluid dynamics. It links weapon design to target effects and survivability.

quote.text: When Barbicane proposed to send a projectile to the Moon…

types.name: Banking
types.description: Banking in the Enlightenment organized capital for commerce and war finance. The Amsterdam Wisselbank stabilized clearing through giro deposits and bullion custody. The Bank of England combined note issue with funded national debt, enabling long-term borrowing at scale. Merchant banks extended bills of exchange and acceptance credit across Atlantic and Asian trades. Stock exchanges and joint-stock ventures broadened investment. States used annuities and lotteries to service obligations. Crises spurred regulation, auditing, and reserve practices that framed later central banking.

quote.text: The banker’s power is felt, not seen.

types.name: Bronze Casting
types.description: Classical artisans used bronze casting to produce durable statues, vessels, tools, and fittings with precise detail. The dominant method was lost‑wax casting. A wax model over a clay core received sprues and vents, then was enclosed in an investment mold and fired to remove the wax. Molten copper‑tin alloy, often 8–12% tin, was poured to form hollow or solid castings. Large works were cast in sections, joined by brazing or mechanical fasteners, then finished by chasing, inlay, and gilding. Greek workshops mastered life‑size and over‑life‑size figures, as seen in the Riace Bronzes. Etruscan founders produced refined candelabra, mirrors, and votive figures for domestic and ritual use. Casting supplied standardized fittings for ships, chariots, and architecture, and small parts for armor. The process supported replication through reusable molds, yet allowed unique surface modeling through wax. The technique spread across the Mediterranean through trade in metals and skilled labor.

quote.text: Once cast, bronze keeps its shape forever.

types.name: Bronze Smithing
types.description: Bronze smithing refined the alloying of copper with tin to produce hard, workable metal for tools, weapons, and prestige goods. Craftsmen mastered smelting, casting in stone or clay molds, and the lost-wax process for complex forms, then improved edges and resilience through hammering and annealing cycles. In classical contexts, Greek workshops produced helmets, cuirasses, and spearheads for hoplites, while Etruscan artisans made highly finished mirrors, cistae, and ritual vessels. Supply chains for tin, scarce in the Mediterranean, linked workshops to distant sources via maritime trade. Surface treatments, riveting, and soldering allowed composite assemblies and repairs. Bronze’s resistance to corrosion and ease of casting sustained its use for statues and architectural fittings even as iron edged tools became common. Guild-like traditions, apprenticeship, and specialized urban quarters maintained technical continuity and style.

quote.text: The smith’s hammer makes crowns and swords alike.

types.name: Bronze Working
types.description: Bronze working alloyed copper with tin to create a harder, more durable metal suited for blades, fittings, and cast forms. Craftspeople smelted ores, blended metals in crucibles, and cast objects using stone molds or lost-wax techniques. Heat treatment and hammer finishing improved edges and toughness. The alloy enabled longer swords, socketed axes, chisels, and complex vessels beyond the limits of pure copper. Demand for tin fostered long-distance trade linking mines to foundries and palace workshops. Mycenaean workshops produced standardized weapon types, while Shang foundries cast ritual vessels of high technical sophistication using sectional molds. Scrap recycling and ingot circulation formed a metal economy that could be mobilized by states. Bronze working transformed warfare, agriculture, and ceremony, and it created specialized labor groups embedded within urban administrative systems.

quote.text: Bronze is the mirror of the brave.

types.name: Bureaucracy
types.description: Bureaucracy denotes a rational administrative order built on hierarchical offices, written procedures, and specialized expertise. In the nineteenth century many states professionalized civil services, separating office from person and securing tenure. Prussia developed examination systems and rule‑bound ministries that other European governments emulated. The Meiji Restoration created centralized ministries and prefectures in Japan, blending Western models with local practice. Standardized forms, statistics, and budgets improved fiscal control. This framework enabled modern taxation, education, infrastructure, and conscription. Max Weber later analyzed bureaucracy as a core feature of modern authority, contrasting it with patrimonial and charismatic rule.

quote.text: Bureaucracy expands to meet the needs of the expanding bureaucracy.

types.name: Buttress
types.description: A buttress is a masonry projection built to counter lateral thrust from roofs and vaults. Medieval builders refined the form to support soaring stone churches. The flying buttress moved the line of thrust from the nave vault to an external pier through an arched flyer. This allowed thinner walls and large stained-glass windows. Early experiments appear in Romanesque works, but full systems matured in 12th–13th century Île-de-France. Engineers added pinnacles to increase compressive load and resist wind. Channels and weatherings shed water from joints. Notable achievements include the networks at Notre-Dame de Paris and Chartres Cathedral. Similar devices strengthened Reims and Canterbury. Buttressing also reinforced castle curtain walls and towers. The principle persisted into later revival styles and informed modern analysis of load paths.

quote.text: Beauty rises from strength unseen.

types.name: Calendar
types.description: Calendars ordered time for agriculture, ritual, and administration. Early systems observed lunar months, solar cycles, and stellar risings to mark seasons and schedule labor. The Egyptian civil calendar standardized a 365-day year with twelve 30-day months and five epagomenal days, aligning taxation and flood preparations despite drift from the true solar year. Babylonian administrators employed a lunisolar scheme, intercalating months to keep festivals and planting aligned with seasons; month names tied to celestial observations. Record-keeping on papyri and tablets used these frameworks to date contracts, rations, and deliveries. Priests and astronomer-scribes monitored new moons, solstices, and the heliacal rising of Sirius to refine predictions. The calendar’s precision underpinned stable ration cycles, temple offerings, and state projects, enabling coordination across regions and years.

quote.text: Read the stars to know when to sow.

types.name: Cartography
types.description: Cartography during the Enlightenment fused mathematics, astronomy, and state administration. Surveyors built national triangulation networks, such as the Cassini project in France, to fix geodetic baselines. Marine cartographers improved coastal charts through systematic sounding and lunar-distance or chronometer-based longitude. James Cook’s Pacific surveys set new standards for accuracy and toponymy. Cadastral mapping supported taxation, conscription, and land reform. Standardized symbols and projections circulated through atlases and naval manuals. Governments and learned societies financed expeditions to close gaps from polar regions to colonial interiors.

quote.text: No man’s land is land unmarked.

types.name: Carvel Hulls
types.description: A carvel hull uses edge-to-edge planking fastened to a robust frame, producing a smooth exterior. Mediterranean shipwrights developed the technique, which Portuguese builders adapted for oceanic caravels and larger carracks. The smooth skin reduced drag and accepted deeper, broader hulls with greater cargo capacity. Frame-first construction eased standardization and repair. Caulking with oakum and pitch sealed seams. Ships built this way mounted heavier masts and, later, artillery. Carvel-built vessels carried Bartolomeu Dias around the Cape of Good Hope and Vasco da Gama to India. Christopher Columbus sailed carvel-rigged Niña and Pinta alongside the larger carrack Santa María. The method underpinned the transition to galleons and line-of-battle ships, anchoring Europe’s long-range navigation and trade.

quote.text: A well-joined plank carries a man to the ends of the earth.

types.name: Castles
types.description: Castles were fortified residences that anchored seigneurial power and protected key routes. Early forms used timber mottes and baileys. From the twelfth century stone keeps, curtain walls, and gatehouses became standard. Designers added towers for flanking fire, arrow slits, hoardings, and later machicolations. Concentric plans layered defenses to absorb sieges. Garrisoned castles stored food, managed courts, and collected dues. They supported field armies and controlled bridges, ports, and passes. Notable examples include Krak des Chevaliers, the Tower of London, and the walls of Carcassonne. Siege artillery and gunpowder changed requirements in the fifteenth century. Many castles were adapted or eclipsed by lower, thicker trace italienne forts. Others shifted toward palatial residence while retaining administrative and jurisdictional roles.

quote.text: He who holds the gate holds the realm.

types.name: Celestial Navigation
types.description: Celestial navigation in the classical world combined empirical star knowledge with simple sighting methods to guide coasting and open-water passages. Phoenician mariners steered by Polaris and circumpolar stars to maintain headings at night, supplementing daytime solar azimuths and wind patterns. Greek sailors used rising and setting points of prominent constellations and seasonal star calendars (parapegmata) to plan departures and routes. Angle estimation employed the hand, gnomons, and basic dioptras long before specialized nautical instruments. Latitude awareness grew from observing the elevation of known stars relative to the horizon, enabling ventures beyond familiar shorelines. Textual traditions linked to Hipparchus and later Ptolemy codified stellar positions and seasonal timings. This astronomical seamanship integrated with dead reckoning and pilotage, supporting Mediterranean trade networks and exploratory voyages such as those attributed to Pytheas.

quote.text: He who knows the stars will not lose his way.

types.name: Chemistry
types.description: Industrial-era chemistry became a laboratory science connected to large-scale production. Building on Lavoisier’s stoichiometry and conservation, nineteenth‑century chemists refined analytic methods, glassware, and instrumentation. Dmitri Mendeleev’s periodic table (1869) organized elements by atomic weight and predicted new ones, guiding research and pedagogy. Organic chemistry grew rapidly after coal‑tar distillation; William Henry Perkin’s aniline dyes sparked a German-led synthetic colorant industry centered at BASF, Bayer, and Hoechst. Industrial chemistry scaled key reagents such as sulfuric acid and alkalis through Leblanc and later Solvay processes, lowering costs for textiles, paper, and metallurgy. Electrochemistry enabled chlorine and aluminum production. Pharmaceutical synthesis, fertilizer development, and explosives chemistry linked university laboratories with factory R&D. By 1900, professional societies, journals, and standardized nomenclature coordinated an international chemical enterprise.

quote.text: Chemistry turns earth into bread, cloth, and light.

types.name: Chivalry
types.description: Chivalry was a knightly code that shaped conduct in war, lordship, and sociability. It stressed loyalty to one's lord, courage under arms, and the defense of the Church. Courtly literature, including chansons de geste and romances, promoted models of prowess and courtesy. Tournament rules and heraldic customs regulated displays of skill and lineage. Crusading vows framed service as both martial and penitential. Jurists and preachers debated limits on violence against noncombatants and clergy. Practice varied by region and time, and real warfare often ignored ideals. Yet the code influenced aristocratic education, legal privileges, and the ritual of knighthood across Latin Christendom.

quote.text: Strength to protect, honor to serve.

types.name: Civil Defense
types.description: Civil defense comprises government programs to protect civilians from attack and major disasters. In the Second World War, Britain organized air raid wardens, enforced blackouts, and built shelters that sustained London during the Blitz. The United States created warning networks and CONELRAD sirens in the early Cold War. Drills, evacuation plans, and fallout shelter mapping followed. Many countries folded civil defense into broader emergency management after the 1960s. The focus shifted toward communication, evacuation, and continuity of government under conventional and technological hazards. Modern systems coordinate local responders, public alerts, and infrastructure protection while retaining contingency plans for aerial and missile threats.

quote.text: Duck and cover!
quote.source: U.S. Federal Civil Defense Administration film, 1951

types.name: Civil Service
types.description: Civil service expanded as European states professionalized administration. Rulers built salaried bureaucracies that collected revenue, kept records, and enforced law. France developed intendants who supervised provinces and bypassed local estates. Habsburg lands assembled chanceries and cameral offices staffed by trained jurists. The Ottoman Empire maintained scribal institutions and undertook administrative reforms alongside timar changes. Merit claims grew with examinations, legal education, and career ladders, though patronage persisted. Central archives and correspondence networks tied capitals to frontier districts. The Spanish Monarchy coordinated its composite realms through councils and audiencias. These systems stabilized governance and supported taxation, war finance, and imperial management.

quote.text: The palest ink is better than the strongest memory.

types.name: Clinker Hulls
types.description: Clinker, or lapstrake, construction fastened overlapping strakes along a light frame to form strong and flexible wooden hulls. Edge-riveted planks created longitudinal stiffness while allowing the shell to work in heavy seas. The method excelled for surf launching and shoal waters, common in the North Atlantic. Viking longships such as Gokstad and Oseberg used clinker hulls for speed, shallow draft, and beaching. From the thirteenth century, Hanseatic cogs adapted clinker sides to broad, capacious trading craft. Caulking with animal hair and tar sealed seams. Builders later combined clinker topsides with carvel bottoms or shifted entirely to carvel for larger artillery-bearing ships. North Sea traders continued clinker practice into the early modern era.

quote.text: Fair is the ship, fast is the seam.

types.name: Code of Law
types.description: Codes of law publicly articulated rules of procedure, property, family relations, and penalties to regularize justice. In the Roman Twelve Tables, provisions were inscribed for consultation by citizens, curbing magistrates’ discretion and establishing due process norms. The Code of Gortyn in Crete recorded detailed regulations on marriage, inheritance, slavery, and fines on a wall in the city. Publication on stone or bronze enabled reference and teaching in courts and assemblies. Codification stabilized precedent, guided magistrates and jurors, and clarified rights across communities. Written law also facilitated administration in colonies and federations by providing portable standards for adjudication.

quote.text: Let justice be seen throughout the land.

types.name: Cold Steel
types.description: Cold steel denotes edged weapons and bayonet fighting used to deliver shock at close range. The socket bayonet allowed muskets to function as spears without removing the barrel from action, displacing the pike. Infantry doctrine in the eighteenth century combined controlled volleys with rapid advance and a decisive charge. Swedish forces in the Great Northern War practiced aggressive assaults at close order. Russian commanders, including Suvorov, stressed the bayonet as the final arbiter. During the Seven Years’ War, European armies executed column or line attacks aimed at breaking cohesion. Training emphasized steadiness, timing, and morale. Though firepower grew, cold steel remained integral for storming works and settling encounters after ammunition expenditure.

quote.text: The sword speaks when words fail.

types.name: Colonialism
types.description: Colonialism in the Enlightenment era involved overseas conquest, settlement, and resource extraction by European states. Maritime empires relied on chartered companies, fortified ports, and naval protection. Spain governed vast American territories through viceroyalties, mines, and missions. The Dutch consolidated the East Indies under the VOC with spice monopolies and coercive trade. Britain expanded colonies in North America and the Caribbean, pairing plantations with the Atlantic slave trade. Legal regimes reorganized land and labor, while surveys and maps asserted claims. Colonial cities such as Mexico City, Batavia, and Boston anchored administration and commerce. These systems reshaped global flows of silver, spices, and agricultural staples.

quote.text: First comes the trader, then the soldier.

types.name: Combined Arms
types.description: Combined arms integrated infantry, cavalry, artillery, and later mechanized and air units into coordinated formations that applied complementary strengths against enemy forces. Commanders organized units to support one another, with infantry holding ground, cavalry or mobile forces maneuvering, and artillery disrupting formations and defenses at range. Communication systems, standardized drill, and staff planning enabled synchronized movement and timing across diverse units. Logistics supplied ammunition, equipment, and transport to sustain operations over distance. This coordination reduced the vulnerabilities of individual unit types and increased battlefield effectiveness. Combined arms allowed militaries to conduct offensive and defensive operations with greater flexibility, concentration of force, and operational control across complex and changing combat conditions.

quote.text: I ain't no fortunate son...

types.name: Combustion
types.description: Combustion is rapid oxidation releasing heat and work. In the industrial era it moved from furnace and boiler practice to scientific design based on thermodynamics and gas chemistry. The Otto four‑stroke engine (1876) converted controlled gasoline combustion into rotary motion with higher efficiency than steam at small scales. Rudolf Diesel’s compression‑ignition engine (1897) used high pressures to ignite heavier fuels, improving fuel economy. Carburetion, ignition timing, and later fuel injection managed flame speed and knock. Internal combustion enabled automobiles, tractors, and light aircraft, while continued boiler firing powered ships and power plants. Study of emissions and flame dynamics followed.

quote.text: The age of distance is ended.

types.name: Commerce
types.description: Commerce formalized exchange through institutions, records, and infrastructure. In Bronze Age cities, temples and palaces managed stores, issued rations, and coordinated long-distance caravans. Merchant houses consolidated goods, arranged credit, and pooled risk for sea voyages and overland journeys. Standard weights and measures allowed value comparison across commodities. Cylinder seals authenticated containers and tablets, securing ownership and documenting transactions. Urban markets concentrated vendors and buyers under periodic or fixed schedules, while harbors and caravanserais supported transit. Silver by weight often served as an accounting unit even when barter persisted. Uruk warehouses illustrate early bulk handling; sealings and bullae track movement from store to store. These practices reduced transaction costs, extended trading horizons, and stabilized supplies of tin, textiles, grain, and timber. Commerce integrated regional economies and sustained craft specialization beyond local subsistence cycles.

quote.text: Let the measure be true and the seal intact.

types.name: Compass
types.description: The magnetic compass provided a steady directional reference independent of sky or coast. Chinese navigators used a magnetized needle in a bowl of water by the Song era, later developing dry-card compasses. Knowledge moved along Asian trade networks to the Indian Ocean and Mediterranean in the thirteenth century. European mariners paired the compass with portolan charts and the sternpost rudder to extend open-sea passages. The nautical box compass, often gimballed, stabilized the card on rolling decks. Mariners learned to allow for variation and deviation, though magnetic declination limited precision. The instrument enabled winter sailing, fog navigation, and longer transits between fixed landfalls, reshaping pilotage and route planning.

quote.text: When the stars are hidden, the needle still guides.

types.name: Composites
types.description: Composites are materials formed by combining reinforcing fibers or particles with a matrix to achieve high strength‑to‑weight ratios and tailored properties. Aerospace adoption accelerated with carbon‑fiber reinforced polymers, culminating in primary structures on the Boeing 787, including fuselage barrels and wings. Motorsports advanced crashworthy monocoques in Formula 1. Wind energy relied on composite blades for stiffness and fatigue resistance at large spans. Processes such as prepreg layup, resin infusion, and automated fiber placement matured with nondestructive inspection techniques. Challenges included repair, recycling of thermoset systems, and cost control. Composites broadened design freedom and improved performance in aviation, marine, sporting goods, and pressure vessels.

quote.text: Stronger than steel, lighter than aluminum.

types.name: Construction
types.description: Classical construction combined stone masonry, timber framing, and concrete to create durable infrastructure and monuments. Greek builders used precisely cut marble and limestone with post-and-lintel systems, refined entasis, and careful jointing. Romans expanded the toolkit with pozzolanic concrete, arches, vaults, and domes. Surveyors laid out roads with standardized layers, camber, and drainage. Aqueducts carried water across valleys on arcades calibrated for gentle gradients. Large projects such as the Colosseum integrated travertine, brick, and concrete with iron cramps and lime mortar. Organization relied on skilled guilds, enslaved labor, and military detachments. Tools included plumb lines, gromas, chorobates, pulleys, and treadwheel cranes. The result was a network of roads, bridges, baths, and temples that sustained urban life and imperial logistics.

quote.text: Stretch the cord by the stars; set the temple true.

types.name: Copper Working
types.description: Copper working emerged from the use of native copper, first cold-hammered into beads and simple tools, then annealed to restore ductility. By the late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, smelting of oxide and carbonate ores became common. Craftspeople cast ingots and tools in open molds and refined edges by hammering. Workshops appear at settlements with evidence of crucibles, slag, and tuyères. Çatalhöyük yielded early copper beads, while Balkan sites produced axe heads and chisels that show increasing metallurgical control. Copper’s softness limited cutting performance compared to later alloys, yet it enabled new tool types, riveted fittings, and ornamental status goods. Knowledge of furnace atmospheres, ore selection, and reworking cycles advanced steadily. These practices created the technical base and specialist communities that later adopted tin alloying, transitioning into bronze metallurgy and expanding the range and durability of metal artifacts.

quote.text: The smith who casts the cup masters the fire.

types.name: Crop Rotation
types.description: Crop rotation in the medieval period was a managed sequence of plantings designed to maintain soil fertility and stable yields. The three-field system spread across northern Europe from the ninth to thirteenth centuries. One field bore autumn-sown cereals, a second spring grains or legumes, and a third lay fallow. Legumes fixed nitrogen, reducing nutrient depletion and improving fodder. Fallow scheduling allowed weed control and grazing that recycled manure. Manorial accounts record rising output and more reliable harvests under the system. Islamic agronomic texts and local practice also promoted multi-year rotations in Iberia and Sicily. Rotations supported population growth by increasing the cropped area and diversifying diets. They enabled heavier plough use and larger draft herds by supplying feed. Notable forms included legume-intensive sequences and reforms that shortened or reorganized fallow. The system endured into early modern agriculture until enclosed fields and new rotations displaced it.

quote.text: Let the land rest every seventh year, and it will reward you in time.

types.name: Currency
types.description: Classical currency standardized value for exchange, taxation, and military pay. States issued coinage in precious metals on regulated weight standards, struck with dies to confirm authority and fineness. Silver issues dominated many markets. The Athenian drachma became a widely accepted medium through maritime trade and tribute systems. In the western Mediterranean, the Roman denarius provided a stable unit for contracts, provisioning, and soldier stipends. Coins moved across borders in bulk, easing accounting and price comparison. Hoards record crises, reforms, and regional circulation. Civic mints adjusted denominations to meet fiscal needs, while debasement and recoinage tracked political change. Currency integrated local markets into larger commercial networks.

quote.text: Silver buys more than a thousand speeches.

types.name: Delivery Services
types.description: Delivery services move goods from depots to consumers through parcel networks, route planning, and last‑mile operations. The sector expanded with e‑commerce, as rapid fulfillment models such as Amazon Prime set time benchmarks. Carriers introduced consumer scheduling tools and real‑time tracking. Urban logistics experimented with micro‑fulfillment, lockers, and electric vans. Platform workforces added flexible capacity via gig‑economy couriers for meals and small parcels. Data analytics optimized load factors and routing, while policy attention grew around labor standards, emissions, and curb access.

quote.text: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night.
quote.source: Inscription, New York City Post Office, 1914

types.name: Democracy
types.description: Classical democracy vested authority in the citizen body through assemblies, councils, and large juries. In Athens, Cleisthenes’ reforms reorganized tribes and established institutions that enabled broad participation. The Assembly set policy, while lottery assigned many offices to limit factional control. Under Pericles, pay for jury and civic service widened access. Legal procedures, ostracism, and public scrutiny structured accountability. Other poleis experimented with mixed constitutions that combined popular and elite elements. Democratic practice depended on military service, taxation, and civic festivals, tying governance to social obligations. Debates over citizenship and empire shaped its limits and legacy.

quote.text: All may speak, but few are heard.

types.name: Diplomacy
types.description: Enlightenment diplomacy developed permanent embassies, coded correspondence, and multilateral congresses. The Peace of Westphalia supplied a legal baseline for sovereignty and nonintervention. The Treaty of Utrecht rebalanced dynastic claims and trade. Resident ambassadors reported intelligence and negotiated alliances within a balance-of-power framework. Protocol, extraterritoriality, and precedence were formalized. Specialized foreign offices managed archives and treaty law. Congresses coordinated settlements after major wars and shaped boundaries across Europe and overseas.

quote.text: An ambassador is an honest man sent to lie abroad.

types.name: Divine Right
types.description: Divine right in the medieval world asserted that a ruler's authority derived from God and was confirmed through ritual and law. In France, Capetian kings received holy unction at Reims, grounding sacral monarchy. Byzantine emperors styled themselves God's vicegerents and presided over an Orthodox court ceremonial. Caliphal legitimacy joined religious leadership with temporal rule in Islamic polities. Coronation oaths and liturgy framed obedience as a moral duty, while resistance risked sacrilege. Contests over investiture and deposition exposed limits, yet the doctrine shaped diplomacy, jurisprudence, and the language of sovereignty well beyond the Middle Ages.

quote.text: I am the state.

types.name: Drama
types.description: Classical drama fused poetry, music, and performance within civic festivals. In Athens, tragedies by Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides examined myth, law, and fate through actors, chorus, and masks on the open‑air stage. Aristophanes’ comedies used satire and topical commentary at the Dionysia. Playwrights composed for competition, with choruses trained at public expense and roles assigned to citizen actors. Theaters with stone seating and orchestra pits shaped acoustics and sightlines. Scripts circulated across the Greek world and later informed Roman adaptations. Drama served education, ritual, and debate, offering shared narratives that tested civic values and political choices.

quote.text: Through the mask, truth is spoken.

types.name: Drilling
types.description: Drilling in the industrial era combined improved power sources, tools, and geological method. Cable‑tool percussion rigs bored early oil and water wells, notably Edwin Drake’s 1859 well at Titusville, Pennsylvania. Rotary drilling, using circulating mud to cool bits and stabilize boreholes, accelerated deep wells and reduced collapses. Diamond‑core drills transformed mineral exploration by retrieving intact cores for assay in European mining districts. Urban water supply advanced through large artesian projects that tapped confined aquifers for growing cities. Steam and then internal‑combustion engines powered portable rigs, extending access to remote sites. Specialized techniques evolved for foundation piles, tunneling probe holes, and blast‑hole patterns in quarries. By the late nineteenth century, standardized casing, threaded pipe, and rudimentary blowout control set the groundwork for modern petroleum and geotechnical practice.

quote.text: The rock yields only to steel and steam.

types.name: Dynamite
types.description: Dynamite, patented by Alfred Nobel in 1867, stabilized liquid nitroglycerin by absorbing it into diatomaceous earth. The cartridge form allowed safer transport, cutting the risk of accidental detonation from shock. Nobel also improved blasting caps and fuses, enabling reliable initiation. Civil engineering adopted dynamite for tunnels, railway cuts, canals, and harbor works, notably in Alpine projects and North American rail construction. Mining expanded deeper and faster as controlled blasts broke rock efficiently. States instituted licensing, magazines, and safety rules to regulate storage and use. Although militaries used dynamite for demolition and torpedoes, cast explosives like picric acid and later TNT became preferred for shells. Nobel’s earnings funded scientific and cultural prizes.

quote.text: Perhaps my dynamite will end war sooner than your congresses.

types.name: Economics
types.description: Economics during the industrial age examined growth, distribution, and crises in mechanized markets. Classical political economy, developed by David Ricardo and others, analyzed comparative advantage and rent. Karl Marx’s Capital offered a historical critique of capitalist production and labor relations. The marginalist revolution of the 1870s, led by Jevons, Menger, and Walras, introduced marginal utility, general equilibrium, and mathematical methods. Empirical statistics, national income accounting precursors, and price series informed policy debates on tariffs, money, and labor. Economics professionalized through journals, societies, and university chairs, shaping legislation on trade, banking, poor relief, and antitrust.

quote.text: Man is a being who desires to possess wealth.

types.name: Education
types.description: Education expanded through reformed universities, academies, and emerging public schools. Curricula added mathematics, natural philosophy, modern languages, and practical surveying. Laboratories and museums supported empirical teaching. States founded teacher seminaries and regulated examinations for professions such as medicine, law, and engineering. Learned societies linked research with instruction through lectures and prize questions. Literacy rates rose in urban centers, aided by cheap print and subscription libraries. Confessional systems persisted, yet secular administration shaped funding, inspection, and textbook production across Europe and colonial settings.

quote.text: The pen is mightier than the sword.

types.name: Electricity
types.description: Electricity became a central industrial technology for power, light, and communication. Telegraph networks in the mid-nineteenth century carried signals across continents and under oceans. Practical generation began with dynamos and direct-current systems, exemplified by Edison’s Pearl Street Station and urban lighting grids. Alternating current, advanced by Nikola Tesla and commercialized by Westinghouse, enabled long-distance transmission and efficient motors. Transformers, switchgear, and distribution networks created utility-scale supply. Electric traction powered streetcars and later suburban rail. Factories adopted motors for flexible layouts beyond shaft-driven lines. Electrification reduced smoke in cities, extended working hours, and supported new industries from electrochemistry to telephone service.

quote.text: Prometheus now lights our wires, not our pyres.

types.name: Engineering
types.description: Medieval engineering applied geometry and mechanics to raise cathedrals, manage water, and wage siege. Master masons designed ribbed vaults and flying buttresses that channelled thrust to piers, enabling tall naves and large windows. Carpenters built scaffolds, centering, and roof trusses with precise joinery. Millwrights expanded watermill and windmill use, adding cams, cranks, and gear trains for grinding, fulling, and hammering. Artillery specialists refined counterweight trebuchets with calibrated sling lengths and release angles. Treatises by Villard de Honnecourt and Jordanus de Nemore documented practice and theory. In the Islamic world, al‑Jazari described automata, pumps, and control mechanisms. Surveying instruments, modular measures, and guild organization supported repeatable construction. Later centuries saw weight-driven clocks and improved metalworking, laying groundwork for early modern mechanics.

quote.text: No fine tower stands without strong foundations.

types.name: Feudalism
types.description: Feudalism is a modern term for medieval arrangements where landholding, protection, and service formed a layered hierarchy.
